pending.headline: Sixty-Six Exits and the Question No One Is Asking
pending.content:
I served twenty-two years in government work. I signed treaties. I attended multilateral meetings. I sat in rooms where nations with opposing interests found ways to coordinate on narrow, technical problems: disease surveillance, solar panel standards, counter-terrorism intelligence, climate data.

Some of those meetings were productive. Some were bureaucratic theater. All of them represented something specific: the willingness of sovereign nations to bind themselves, however loosely, to shared rules.

This week, the United States withdrew from sixty-six international organizations by presidential memorandum.

Not through Senate debate. Not through public hearings on what these bodies do or whether American participation serves American interests. By executive pen, in a single afternoon, citing "globalist agendas" and "wasted taxpayer dollars."

Included in the list: the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, the foundation of all international climate diplomacy. The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, which coordinates the world's leading scientists on temperature data. The International Solar Alliance. The Global Counter-Terrorism Forum. The International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance.

Sixty-six organizations. One memo.

This is not about climate policy. This is about the architecture of accountability.

## The Constitutional Question

The Constitution specifies that the president may make treaties "provided two thirds of Senators present concur." It does not specify what happens when a president withdraws from them.

That silence has created a loophole large enough to drive an entire foreign policy through.

The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change was signed by President George H.W. Bush in 1992 and ratified by the Senate with a vote of unanimous consent. It was not a partisan document. It committed the United States to participate in international efforts to monitor and address climate change, a commitment twenty-eight years in the making.

It now ends, for the second time in five years, by memorandum.

No Senate vote. No public process. No debate over whether the benefits of participation outweigh the costs, whether American scientists should be blocked from attending IPCC meetings in China, whether withdrawing from the Global Counter-Terrorism Forum serves national security.

Just the assertion that these bodies no longer serve American interests, as determined by one person.

The precedent is breathtaking.

## What Withdrawal Actually Means

I want to be specific about what some of these organizations do, because "globalist agenda" is a phrase designed to stop thought rather than invite it.

The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change does not impose carbon taxes. It does not regulate American industry. It provides a forum where nations share temperature data, coordinate emissions monitoring, and negotiate voluntary commitments. American withdrawal means American scientists will be excluded from climate research collaborations. It means the next generation of IPCC reports, which guide global understanding of warming trends, may be delayed or published without American input.

The Global Counter-Terrorism Forum coordinates intelligence sharing among forty member nations on terrorist financing, border security, and emerging threats. Withdrawal does not make America safer. It makes American intelligence agencies less informed.

The International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance studies election security, voting systems, and democratic governance. It has no enforcement power. It publishes research.

These are not shadowy cabals imposing world government. They are technical bodies doing the unglamorous work of international coordination. The United States participated in them because participation provided information, influence, and early warning of problems that do not stop at borders.

Withdrawal is not a reassertion of sovereignty. It is the voluntary abandonment of influence.

## The Normalization of Unilateral Power

I have watched this pattern before. In different contexts, under different administrations, with different justifications.

An emergency power is asserted. It is used. It becomes normal. The next use is broader. The emergency becomes the baseline.

What we are witnessing is the normalization of unilateral withdrawal from binding commitments made by previous governments and ratified by the Senate. The principle being established is that any president may exit any treaty, at any time, for any reason, without legislative consultation.

That principle does not stop with climate agreements or democracy institutes.

If a president may withdraw from the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change without Senate approval, may they withdraw from NATO without Senate approval? From the Geneva Conventions? From mutual defense treaties with Japan or South Korea?

The White House will say those are different. But on what constitutional basis? If the ratification power resides in the Senate but the withdrawal power resides solely in the executive, then treaty commitments are only as durable as the current occupant of the Oval Office.

That is not a treaty. That is a memo.

## What We Are Not Asking

The debate over these withdrawals has focused on climate science, on whether global warming is real, on whether international cooperation is good policy.

Those are important questions. They are not the constitutional question.

The constitutional question is this: Can a president, acting alone, nullify commitments made by the United States government and ratified by the Senate?

If the answer is yes, then the Senate's treaty power is ornamental. Any international commitment can be undone by the next election. America's word lasts four years.

If the answer is no, then these withdrawals should be challenged in court, and Congress should clarify through statute what the withdrawal process requires.

We are not having that debate. We are having a debate about climate models and taxpayer dollars and globalism, as if those are the questions that matter most.

They are not. The question that matters most is whether the constitutional process for making and keeping commitments still binds the executive branch.

No one in power seems interested in asking it.

## The Pattern Across Administrations

I am not blind to history. Presidents of both parties have stretched executive power. President Obama used executive action to enter the Paris Climate Agreement without Senate ratification, precisely because he knew the Senate would not ratify it. President Trump withdrew from it by the same unilateral method.

Both actions were constitutionally questionable. Both normalized the idea that international commitments do not require legislative process.

The difference now is scale. Sixty-six organizations in one day. Not controversial treaties subject to partisan divide, but technical bodies on solar energy and election security and scientific research.

The assertion is not that these specific agreements are flawed. The assertion is that the president has plenary authority to exit any international commitment, for any reason, without constraint.

That assertion is incompatible with the constitutional design.

## What Is Being Lost

When the United States withdraws from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, American scientists lose access to the coordinated global research that shapes understanding of temperature trends, sea level rise, and extreme weather patterns.

When we withdraw from the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance, we lose the ability to share intelligence on election interference and authoritarian tactics threatening democratic systems worldwide.

When we withdraw from the Global Counter-Terrorism Forum, we lose real-time coordination with allies on terrorist financing networks.

These are not symbolic losses. They are operational losses. They make America less informed, less influential, and less secure.

But the greater loss is constitutional. We are normalizing the idea that binding commitments are not binding. That the word of the United States lasts only until the next administration. That treaties ratified by the Senate can be discarded by a president who finds them inconvenient.

If that becomes the standard, no nation will negotiate durable agreements with us. Why would they? Our commitments mean nothing.

## The Test Before Us

The Constitution created a system of separated powers because the Founders understood that concentrated authority, even in well-meaning hands, tends toward tyranny.

The treaty power was deliberately shared between the executive and legislative branches. The president negotiates. The Senate consents. Both are required.

That design was not an accident. It was meant to ensure that international commitments reflected the deliberate judgment of the American people through their representatives, not the preferences of a single executive.

If withdrawal from treaties requires no Senate involvement, then that design is dead.

This is not a partisan argument. It is a constitutional one. The question is not whether climate agreements are good policy. The question is whether the process by which we make and break international commitments still reflects the constitutional structure.

It does not.

Sixty-six organizations. One memo. No debate.

That is not how a republic governs. That is how an executive rules.

The question we should be asking is not whether these organizations served American interests. The question we should be asking is whether a single person, without legislative check, should have the power to exit commitments made by the United States government.

The answer is in the Constitution. We need only look.

In Union there is Strength.

The President of the United States has announced that America needs to "own" Greenland, the sovereign territory of a NATO ally, to prevent Russian or Chinese control. He has offered to do this "the easy way or the hard way." The White House confirms it will not rule out annexing this territory by force.

This is not a negotiating position. This is a declaration that might makes right.

I spent years in service to this country's defense. I know the strategic importance of Arctic territory. I know the value of early warning systems and the challenges of monitoring Russian submarine activity. I know that Greenland's location matters to American security.

But I also know this: We already have a base there. We already have defense agreements. We already have the capability to bring as many troops as we need under existing treaties with Denmark. The strategic value is secured.

So what, exactly, requires ownership?

The president says countries need ownership, not leases. That leases are insufficient for defense. That America must possess Greenland because we cannot trust agreements with allies.

Think about what that means.

It means treaties are worthless. It means alliances are temporary. It means that when strategic interest demands it, sovereign borders become suggestions. It means the United States, when it perceives necessity, will take what it wants from those weaker than itself.

This isn't about Greenland's minerals or its melting ice revealing rare earth deposits. This is about whether law constrains power or merely decorates it.

The Greenlandic people have spoken clearly: "We do not want to be Americans, we do not want to be Danes, we want to be Greenlanders. The future of Greenland must be decided by the Greenlandic people." Their political leaders, across parties, issued a joint statement. This is not a divided population waiting for liberation. This is a people defending their right to self-determination.

Self-determination. The principle America claimed in 1776. The principle we supposedly fought for in two world wars. The principle enshrined in the UN Charter that our NATO allies invoked this week: "sovereignty, territorial integrity and the inviolability of borders."

Unless, apparently, we decide otherwise.

**What Alliances Mean**

Denmark is a NATO member. NATO operates on Article 5: an attack on one is an attack on all. It is the most successful military alliance in history precisely because its members trust that their sovereignty will be respected, that their territorial integrity is guaranteed by collective defense.

Now the United States is threatening to seize territory from a NATO ally. By force if necessary.

Denmark's foreign ministry stated that military action against Greenland would spell the end of NATO. That is not hyperbole. That is a simple statement of fact. An alliance whose leading member annexes territory from another member has no meaning. It is not an alliance. It is a protection racket.

Every NATO member now must ask: If America will threaten Denmark, what prevents them from threatening us? If strategic interest outweighs treaty obligations with Copenhagen, why would it not outweigh them with Warsaw, with Tallinn, with Vilnius?

The President says NATO needs to understand this. What NATO understands is that American security guarantees may be worthless if they conflict with American ambitions.

**The Venezuela Precedent**

This isn't happening in isolation. Days before the Greenland statements, the administration used military force to seize Venezuela's president. Whatever one thinks of Nicolás Maduro, whatever crimes he may have committed, the United States deployed military power to extract a head of state from a sovereign nation.

The easy way or the hard way.

The pattern is clear. When the President determines that American interests require it, sovereign borders become irrelevant. International law becomes optional. The wishes of the people living in those territories become background noise.

This is how empires think. This is not how republics think.

James Madison wrote in Federalist 41: "Security against foreign danger is one of the primitive objects of civil society. It is an avowed and essential object of the American Union." He was right. National security is fundamental. But Madison also knew that republics could become empires, that the pursuit of security could become the pursuit of dominion.

Security justifies defense. It does not justify conquest.

**What Citizens Should Ask**

The question isn't whether Greenland is strategically valuable. The question is whether strategic value justifies taking sovereign territory by force.

The question isn't whether Denmark would sell Greenland. Denmark has said clearly it will not, and Greenland's people have said they don't want to be sold. The question is whether that refusal matters.

The question isn't whether America has the military power to take Greenland. We obviously do. The question is whether power alone determines right.

The question isn't whether other nations would do the same. Russia annexed Crimea using precisely this logic: strategic necessity, historical connection, the wishes of great powers overriding the sovereignty of small nations. We condemned it then. The question is whether we will embrace it now.

Every American should ask: If strategic interest justifies seizing friendly territory, what principle limits that power? If treaty obligations can be discarded when inconvenient, what promises can any nation trust? If the rule of law applies only when expedient, why have law at all?

These aren't abstract questions. These are the questions that determine whether we remain a republic or become something else.

**The Architecture of Restraint**

The American system was built on a profound distrust of concentrated power. The Founders understood that good intentions do not make tyranny impossible. They understood that today's emergency becomes tomorrow's precedent. They understood that power, once claimed, is rarely surrendered.

That's why they built restraints. Separation of powers. Federalism. Enumerated authorities. The requirement that treaties be ratified by the Senate. The principle that Congress alone declares war.

These restraints exist because the Founders knew that executives claiming emergency always have reasons. The threat is always real. The necessity is always pressing. The action is always temporary.

And the precedent is always permanent.

When the President says we need to own Greenland "the easy way or the hard way," he is not just threatening Denmark. He is declaring that American power answers to no law but necessity, to no authority but itself.

That is not the statement of a republic. That is the statement of an empire.

**In Union There is Strength**

Our alliances were built on shared principle, not shared profit. We defended Europe not because it enriched us but because we believed in collective security, in the rule of law, in the sovereignty of nations. We built NATO not to extract tribute but to prevent aggression.

Those alliances made us stronger. Not because we dominated them, but because they trusted us. Trust is strategic value. Trust is what allows forward basing. Trust is what enables intelligence sharing. Trust is what makes collective defense possible.

Threatening to seize Greenland destroys that trust. Saying "the easy way or the hard way" to an ally destroys that trust. Making NATO members wonder if their sovereignty is contingent on our convenience destroys that trust.

Trust, once lost, cannot be rebuilt by force.

The Greenlandic people have said they want to remain Greenlandic. Denmark has said the territory is not for sale. Our NATO allies have reaffirmed their commitment to sovereignty and territorial integrity. The question is whether America will honor those principles or abandon them in pursuit of strategic advantage.

That question, unanswered, defines who we are.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Witness Becomes Crime
pending.content:
I have watched governments restrict press access before. I have seen authorities justify closing borders and controlling information in the name of security. I have reviewed intelligence dossiers that justified surveillance in wartime. But I have never seen a democratic state ban humanitarian organizations for the crime of describing what they see.

That is what Israel has done.

On January 1, Israel barred Doctors Without Borders and approximately forty other international aid groups from entering Gaza and the West Bank. The stated reason: failure to meet new "security and transparency standards." The practical effect: silencing independent witnesses to what is happening in a territory under military occupation.

This isn't about Hamas. This is about accountability.

## The Mechanism of Control

The new Israeli registration requirements are precise. Aid groups must provide complete disclosure of all staff identities and roles. They must not engage in "delegitimization activities against Israel" or "legal persecution of IDF soldiers." Their licenses can be revoked for supporting findings that Israel opposes, including international legal determinations.

These are not security measures. These are speech codes.

Consider what Israel demands: aid workers must hand over staff lists to a party to the conflict, knowing that more than 400 aid workers have been killed in Gaza in the past two years. They must refrain from documenting what international law defines as potential war crimes. They must not testify to what they witness if that testimony might be used in international courts.

This is asking humanitarian workers to choose between bearing witness and maintaining access. It is making documentation itself a disqualifying act.

## When Neutrality Requires Silence

Doctors Without Borders has operated in conflict zones for decades. It treated casualties in Chechnya, Syria, Yemen. It maintained presence under Taliban rule, in territories controlled by ISIS, in regions where governments and insurgents both operated. It did so by maintaining strict neutrality: treating all wounded regardless of faction, documenting conditions without political judgment, and speaking truthfully about what its medical teams observe.

Israel now says this constitutes abandonment of neutrality.

The charge is revealing. What Israel calls "delegitimization" is what medical organizations call testimony. MSF staff described children with severe burns from Israeli airstrikes. They documented malnutrition consistent with famine conditions. They reported seeing people shot while seeking food at distribution sites Israel established and protected.

These are observations, not accusations. They are recorded in medical files, verified by physical evidence, corroborated across multiple facilities.

Israel's position is that such descriptions are inherently hostile. That bearing witness is itself an act of delegitimization. That neutrality requires not documenting suffering if that documentation might support legal claims Israel disputes.

This is not how free societies treat evidence.

## The Constitutional Question

The United States faces a version of this question constantly: when does national security justify restricting information? When can the government control who may enter zones of conflict? When does operational necessity trump the public's right to independent verification?

The answers are established in law and precedent. The government may restrict access for specific military necessity, but not to prevent documentation of its actions. It may classify information that would compromise operations, but not embarrass officials. It may control borders, but not to ensure only favorable accounts emerge.

James Madison wrote in the Virginia Report of 1800 that "a popular Government, without popular information, or the means of acquiring it, is but a Prologue to a Farce or a Tragedy." He was defending the right of citizens to receive information even during the quasi-war with France. The principle was that representative government requires informed judgment, and informed judgment requires independent access to facts.

The Israeli ban operates in reverse. It ensures that only official accounts reach the public. It removes independent medical verification. It eliminates the possibility of documentation that might contradict state narratives.

This is not unique to Israel. Governments at war have always sought to control information. What is new is claiming this as a legitimate security measure compatible with democratic governance. What is dangerous is the precedent: that humanitarian access can be conditioned on political silence, that bearing witness can be classified as hostile activity, that medical testimony can be suppressed as delegitimization.

## The American Interest

The United States provides military aid to Israel under laws requiring that recipients not restrict humanitarian assistance. The Foreign Assistance Act conditions aid on compliance with international humanitarian law. The Leahy Law prohibits assistance to units credibly accused of gross human rights violations.

These laws assume verification. They assume independent monitors can document conditions. They assume the United States can base policy on facts rather than assurances.

The Israeli ban eliminates that assumption. It removes the independent observers whose reports inform congressional oversight. It ensures that future assessments of humanitarian conditions will rely on Israeli military sources or exhausted local staff working without international expertise, supplies, or protection.

This affects American law. It affects American appropriations. It affects American compliance with statutes governing foreign assistance. And it creates a precedent: that recipients of American military aid may restrict access, control information, and prevent documentation of how that aid is used.

That precedent extends beyond this conflict. If conditioning humanitarian access on political silence is acceptable, then every recipient of American assistance has a model. If removing independent witnesses is justified by security necessity, then oversight becomes optional. If medical testimony can be classified as delegitimization, then evidence becomes whatever the government says it is.

## What History Shows

In 1968, the My Lai massacre remained hidden for over a year because independent journalists had limited access to operational areas in Vietnam. When exposed, the revelations shocked the American public and changed the conduct of the war. The lesson was not that the press should have been excluded further. It was that military operations in a democracy require independent verification precisely because governments cannot be trusted to investigate themselves.

During the Balkan conflicts of the 1990s, humanitarian organizations provided the documentation that later formed the basis for war crimes prosecutions. The Srebrenica massacre, initially denied by Serbian forces and obscured by competing claims, was verified through medical examinations, refugee interviews, and physical evidence collected by aid workers who maintained access through the conflict.

The pattern is consistent. Independent witnesses serve not the enemy but the historical record. They provide evidence that can support or refute claims by all parties. Their presence constrains atrocities not by preventing them but by ensuring they will be documented, investigated, and judged.

Israel now says such documentation is illegitimate. That the presence of observers who might testify against state actions is itself a security threat. That humanitarian access must be conditioned on silence about what is witnessed.

This is the logic of impunity.

## The Test Before Us

The question is not whether Israel's security concerns are legitimate. The question is whether those concerns justify eliminating independent verification of what occurs in occupied territory.

The question is not whether aid organizations have political views. The question is whether medical observations constitute delegitimization or evidence.

The question is not whether Israel has the power to impose these restrictions. The question is whether such restrictions are compatible with democratic governance, international humanitarian law, and American legal obligations.

These are not abstract questions. They determine whether independent fact-finding is possible in conflict zones. They determine whether medical testimony is protected or can be classified as hostile activity. They determine whether American military assistance enables actions that cannot withstand documentation.

The answers matter beyond this conflict. They establish whether democracies at war must tolerate independent verification or may remove witnesses. They establish whether conditioning aid on political silence is a legitimate security measure or suppression of evidence. They establish whether international humanitarian law means what it says or can be suspended when documentation becomes inconvenient.

## A 14-year-old needs surgery his mother cannot afford. An 8-year-old with severe burns needs specialized care unavailable in Gaza's shattered hospitals. A young man with shrapnel wounds needs physical therapy his body will never fully recover without.

These are not abstractions. These are people named in medical files at MSF clinics that may close because Israel has classified medical testimony as delegitimization.

The constitutional question is whether a society that values liberty can support restrictions on humanitarian access designed to prevent documentation of suffering. The policy question is whether the United States should condition military assistance on allowing independent verification. The moral question is whether we are comfortable with a precedent that treats bearing witness as grounds for exclusion.

Those questions remain open. The closures proceed.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When the President Promises Meetings He Cannot Deliver
pending.content:
I spent years in government. You learn to read the distance between what is said and what can actually be done.

President Trump says Iran wants to negotiate. He says a meeting is being set up. Iran's government has said nothing of the kind.

This is not a diplomatic breakthrough. This is something else entirely.

## The Pattern of Claimed Authority

Trump has threatened military strikes against Iran over its crackdown on protesters. Death toll: at least 544. More than 10,600 detained. The internet is shut down. Phone lines are cut. Iran's Revolutionary Guard is sending text messages warning parents to keep their children off the streets or face charges of treason.

The President says he may have to act before any meeting takes place. "We may have to act because of what's happening before the meeting."

Here is the constitutional question: On what authority would the United States strike Iran to protect Iranian protesters from their own government?

Not treaty obligation. Not defense of American forces. Not imminent threat to the homeland.

Humanitarian intervention by unilateral presidential order.

That's not in Article II. It's not anywhere in the Constitution. Congress has the power to declare war. The President is Commander in Chief of forces Congress authorizes. Even the War Powers Resolution, passed over a presidential veto in 1973, requires notification within 48 hours and withdrawal within 60 days absent congressional authorization.

Trump is discussing military action as if it requires only his decision. As if Iran's internal brutality, however horrific, creates presidential war power by executive will alone.

This is how constitutional boundaries disappear, not through dramatic confrontation but through the quiet assertion that what was never authorized has somehow become permissible.

## The Diplomatic Claim That Cannot Be Verified

"Iran called, they want to negotiate."

Iran's Foreign Minister just told foreign diplomats in Tehran that "the situation has come under total control." He blamed the U.S. and Israel for the violence. He called for pro-government rallies. Iranian state television broadcast chants of "Death to America!"

That is not the posture of a government seeking talks.

Oman's Foreign Minister did travel to Iran this weekend. Oman has served as an intermediary before, most notably in the negotiations that led to the 2015 nuclear agreement. But intermediation requires two parties willing to talk.

What we have instead is a president claiming negotiations are imminent while threatening strikes, and an Iranian government showing no interest in compromise while conducting a violent crackdown.

This matters because the claim of negotiations justifies delay in congressional consultation. If talks are happening, if a diplomatic solution is within reach, then perhaps Congress need not be involved yet. Perhaps the President needs flexibility.

But if no negotiations are actually happening, then what we have is the executive branch manufacturing a justification for unilateral action while sidelining the legislative branch's constitutional role in decisions about war.

James Madison warned against this in Federalist 51: "Ambition must be made to counteract ambition." The separation of powers exists precisely to prevent one branch from claiming authority it does not possess.

## The Crisis That Justifies Anything

The situation in Iran is genuinely terrible. Protesters are being killed. The internet blackout prevents verification of what is happening. The government is warning parents their children will be charged with treason for demonstrating.

This creates real moral pressure to do something.

But "something must be done" has justified nearly every expansion of executive power in American history. The Alien and Sedition Acts. Suspension of habeas corpus. Japanese internment. Warrantless surveillance. Indefinite detention. Drone strikes without congressional authorization.

Each time, the emergency was real. Each time, the claim was that normal constitutional processes were too slow, too cumbersome, inadequate to the crisis.

Each time, the expansion of executive power persisted long after the emergency ended.

Lincoln suspended habeas corpus to preserve the Union. The government still claims authority to detain American citizens without trial as enemy combatants. That's 160 years of constitutional erosion stemming from a Civil War emergency.

The question is not whether Iran's government is brutal. It is.

The question is whether that brutality authorizes the American President to launch military strikes without congressional authorization.

The answer under the Constitution is no.

## What Accountability Looks Like

Trump's national security team is weighing "cyberattacks and direct strikes by the U.S. or Israel." Anonymous sources. Not authorized to comment publicly.

If the President orders strikes, will he notify Congress within 48 hours as the War Powers Resolution requires?

Will he seek congressional authorization if operations continue beyond 60 days?

Will he claim that protecting protesters from their government constitutes defense of vital national interests?

Will Congress insist on its constitutional role, or will it defer to executive judgment?

These are not hypothetical questions. This is how we find out whether the Constitution still governs decisions about war, or whether it has become merely advisory when the President believes circumstances require action.

Iran's parliament speaker warned that U.S. military forces and Israel would be "legitimate targets" if America uses force. That means American service members' lives would be at risk.

Those service members swore an oath to support and defend the Constitution. They are entitled to know that when they are sent into harm's way, it is pursuant to constitutional authority, not presidential assertion.

## The Silence That Matters Most

Congress has said almost nothing.

No demand for briefings. No insistence on consultation before any military action. No assertion of its constitutional role in decisions about war.

Just silence.

That silence is more dangerous than Trump's threats. Presidents will always claim emergency power. What matters is whether Congress defends its constitutional role.

If it does not, if it simply accepts presidential claims to unilateral war-making authority, then the constitutional structure for decisions about war has effectively been amended without going through Article V.

Not by vote. Not by debate. By acquiescence.

This is not about Trump or Iran or this particular crisis. It's about whether Congress will defend its constitutional role in decisions that risk American lives, or whether that role has simply been surrendered to the executive branch.

The test of constitutional government is not whether power is used wisely. It is whether power is exercised lawfully.

Right now, a president is threatening military action without clear constitutional authority, claiming negotiations that cannot be verified, and facing no meaningful congressional constraint.

That is not how the Constitution allocates war powers.

The question for Congress is simple: Do you still claim your constitutional role, or have you given it away?

The silence is the answer.

pending.headline: When Elections Become Rituals
pending.content:
I have stood in polling places on three continents. I have watched citizens in new democracies wait hours to cast ballots they believed would matter. I have also stood in places where voting was theater, where the outcome was known, where the process existed not to choose leaders but to ratify power already held.

What is happening in Uganda is not an election in the sense we understand it. It is a ritual of legitimation.

President Yoweri Museveni has ruled for forty years. He came to power in 1986 condemning leaders who "want to overstay in power." That was the year I graduated from college. Children born when he took office are now forty years old, have children of their own, and have never known another president. His son commands the military and posts on social media about his inevitable succession.

This is not democracy. This is dynasty with electoral aesthetics.

## The Architecture of Inevitability

The internet is shut down. Hundreds of activists are detained. Opposition rallies are dispersed with tear gas. Journalists face restrictions. The challenger campaigns in body armor because he has been shot by police. Voters are barred from observing vote counts.

The government calls these measures "security."

That word does important work. It transforms repression into protection. It makes the abnormal sound responsible. It suggests that shutting down communications, arresting dissidents, and blocking election monitors are not instruments of control but responses to threat.

This is how temporary becomes permanent. This is how exception becomes rule.

The Uganda Communications Commission says the internet blackout is "a precautionary intervention to ensure peace, protect national stability and prevent the misuse of communication platforms during a sensitive national exercise." Note the language: precautionary, ensure, protect, prevent. This is the vocabulary of guardianship, not governance. It assumes that the population cannot be trusted with information during the very moment they are asked to make decisions about their future.

James Madison understood what this reveals: "A popular government, without popular information, or the means of acquiring it, is but a prologue to a farce or a tragedy, or perhaps both."

## The Performance of Consent

Elections under these conditions serve a purpose, but it is not selection. They demonstrate reach. They map support. They identify opposition. They create the appearance of legitimacy for international consumption. They let the government claim a mandate.

Most importantly, they normalize the arrangement.

Every time this happens without consequence, the idea that it could be otherwise recedes. The opposition candidate campaigns despite knowing he will not be allowed to win. Voters cast ballots despite knowing the outcome. International observers issue reports. Western governments express concern. And nothing changes.

This is not accident. This is design.

The process teaches learned helplessness. It demonstrates that resistance is performative, that opposition is tolerated only when it is ineffective, that the forms of democracy can persist indefinitely without any of its substance.

I have seen this before. I watched it in places where militaries held elections to demonstrate civilian support. I watched it in places where one-party states held votes to show popular approval. The mechanics differ. The lesson is the same: power concedes nothing without compulsion, and compulsion requires organization that the state will not permit.

## The Question of Legitimacy

Here is what matters: Museveni is strategically valuable to Western governments. He deploys troops to trouble spots. He accepts deportees. He cooperates on counterterrorism. He is, in the language of realpolitik, "our son of a bitch."

This calculation is not new. It justified support for autocrats throughout the Cold War. It justified relationships with regimes that imprisoned dissidents, banned opposition, controlled media, and called it stability.

The question is whether those relationships undermine the very principles they claim to defend.

When we accept that elections can be theater as long as the theater serves our interests, we are not defending democracy. We are defending its opposite. We are saying that legitimacy comes from cooperation with us, not consent of the governed.

Abraham Lincoln said it plainly: "No man is good enough to govern another man without that other's consent."

That principle does not have a geopolitical exception.

## What We Are Watching

Twenty-one million Ugandans are registered to vote. Most are under forty. They have lived their entire lives under one ruler. They are voting in an election where the internet is shut down, activists are jailed, opposition is harassed, and observers are blocked.

Some will vote for Museveni because they support him. Some will vote for him because they fear the alternative. Some will vote for the opposition knowing it will not matter. Some will not vote at all.

But they will all absorb the lesson that power does not change through peaceful means, that law protects authority rather than rights, that elections are not mechanisms of accountability but ceremonies of submission.

That lesson does not stay in Uganda. It travels. It spreads. It becomes precedent.

Every time an election happens under these conditions without consequence, the idea that it must be otherwise weakens. Every time we accept strategic autocracy as lesser evil, we erode the ground on which free societies stand.

## The Test

The question is not what will happen in Uganda. We know what will happen. Museveni will be declared the winner. There will be allegations of fraud. There will be international statements. There will be no change.

The question is what that means for the principle that legitimate government derives from the consent of the governed.

If that principle matters, it matters everywhere. If it matters everywhere, it cannot coexist with tactical exceptions. If we defend democracy only where it serves our interests, we do not defend democracy. We defend interests.

I am not suggesting military intervention. I am not proposing sanctions. I am asking whether we have the clarity to call this what it is.

This is not an election. This is a demonstration that elections can exist without democracy, that the forms can persist without the substance, that legitimacy can be claimed without consent.

That question, unanswered, is why this still matters.

pending.headline: When Federal Force Becomes the First Response
pending.content:
I served under rules of engagement more restrictive than what we're seeing in American cities.

That's not a political statement. It's a fact. In Iraq, in Afghanistan, our authority to use force was bounded by law, by treaty, by chain of command, and by the knowledge that every shot fired would be investigated. We operated in combat zones under stricter accountability than ICE agents are operating in Minneapolis.

This matters now because the President has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act to suppress protests against federal law enforcement operations. Not to repel an invasion. Not to restore order after state authority has collapsed. To quell opposition to how federal agents are conducting immigration enforcement.

That's a different use of the military than the law contemplates.

The Insurrection Act of 1807 permits the President to deploy active-duty military forces for domestic law enforcement under specific circumstances: when state authorities request help, when rebellion makes it impossible to enforce federal law, or when civil rights are being systematically denied. It has been invoked sparingly, twenty-nine times in 217 years, most recently in 1992 during the Los Angeles riots after California's governor requested assistance.

President Trump has threatened to invoke it not because Minnesota lacks the capacity to maintain order, but because Minnesota officials oppose how federal agents are operating within their jurisdiction.

That's not the same thing.

## What Happened in Minneapolis

The facts are these: On January 7, 2026, an ICE agent shot and killed Renee Nicole Good during what the administration calls a law enforcement operation and what video footage shows as a woman attempting to drive away while an agent stood in front of her vehicle. Three shots. The FBI is investigating.

One week later, an ICE agent shot another man in the leg after what DHS characterizes as an ambush with a snow shovel and broom handle. Protests followed. Property was damaged. Federal vehicles were vandalized.

The President then threatened to send in the military if state and local officials did not "stop the professional agitators and insurrectionists."

The predicate for military deployment is not that protests became disorderly. It is that civil authority has failed to function. There is no evidence that Minnesota lacks the capability to maintain order. The state has not requested assistance. The governor has asked to "turn the temperature down," not for troops.

What we're seeing instead is a federal operation generating local resistance, that resistance being labeled insurrection, and military force being threatened to suppress it.

## The Architecture of Accountability

Three thousand federal officers have been deployed to Minnesota. That is more federal law enforcement personnel than are permanently stationed in most states. They are conducting what ICE calls Operation Metro Surge, making arrests, conducting raids, and using force under circumstances that remain unclear because the operations are not subject to the transparency requirements that govern local police.

When a city police officer shoots someone, there are procedures. Body cameras. Use-of-force reviews. Public accountability through local government. When an ICE agent shoots someone, the investigation happens within DHS, the footage may or may not be released, and local officials have no authority to compel answers.

Now imagine 3,000 such officers operating in a city whose mayor has demanded they leave, whose governor has compared them to the Gestapo, and whose residents are watching videos of federal agents shooting people and wondering whether the law applies.

That is not a stable equilibrium.

The administration's response is to threaten military deployment against citizens protesting federal actions. Not deployment to assist local authorities in maintaining order. Deployment to override local opposition to federal operations.

That changes what the Insurrection Act means.

## The History That Matters

The Act was written in 1807, expanded during Reconstruction, and refined after the civil rights era. It has been used to integrate schools, to suppress the Ku Klux Klan, to restore order after riots, and to enforce federal law when states attempted to nullify it.

It has never been used, as far as I can determine, to suppress protests against how federal agents are conducting law enforcement operations within a jurisdiction where civil authority continues to function.

This matters because the Act was designed as a last resort when the constitutional order breaks down. What we're seeing instead is its use being threatened as a first resort when local officials object to federal tactics.

That is a different kind of power.

When federal force becomes the answer to political opposition, when dissent is labeled insurrection, when local accountability is replaced by federal immunity, you have moved from law enforcement to something else.

You have moved toward the kind of federal supremacy the Founders feared.

## What Citizens Should Be Asking

The question is not whether immigration laws should be enforced. The question is under what constraints, with what accountability, and subject to whose authority.

When federal agents operate in American cities under rules less restrictive than soldiers operate under in combat zones, something has gone wrong.

When 3,000 federal officers deploy without local consent or meaningful local oversight, something has changed.

When the military is threatened against citizens protesting federal operations, not because civil authority has failed but because it disagrees, something fundamental has shifted.

James Madison wrote in Federalist 51 that "ambition must be made to counteract ambition." The system works when power checks power, when federal authority is balanced by state authority, when accountability runs through multiple channels.

What happens when federal force operates beyond state oversight, when protests against it are labeled insurrection, when the remedy for local opposition is military deployment?

You get power without accountability.

You get force without constraint.

You get exactly what the Constitution was designed to prevent.

## The Test

I took an oath to support and defend the Constitution. That oath didn't include partisan caveats. It didn't say "support this administration's policies" or "defend these particular outcomes." It said defend the constitutional order.

That order includes the principle that federal power is limited, that states retain authority, that accountability matters, and that force is employed under law, not instead of it.

When an ICE agent shoots someone, there should be a transparent investigation. When 3,000 federal officers deploy to a city, there should be clarity about their authority and constraints. When the President threatens to send in the military, there should be a clear predicate that goes beyond "local officials object to our operations."

These are not partisan questions. They are constitutional questions about how power works in a republic.

Right now in Minneapolis, federal agents are operating under unclear authority, with limited accountability, generating local opposition that is being labeled insurrection, with military force threatened as the remedy.

If that becomes normal, something essential has been lost.

The Insurrection Act was meant to preserve constitutional government, not to override it when local officials resist federal operations. The difference matters. The precedent matters. The normalization of military force as a response to political disagreement matters.

This isn't about whether you support aggressive immigration enforcement. It's about whether such enforcement operates under law, with accountability, subject to constitutional constraint.

That question, unanswered, is why this moment matters.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Coercion Becomes Policy
pending.content:
I served in government long enough to know how power moves, how it tests boundaries, how it transforms means into ends. What we're witnessing in Minneapolis isn't merely federal immigration enforcement. It's a stress test of constitutional architecture, conducted with tear gas and funding threats.

The facts are straightforward. Federal agents surge into cities. A civilian is killed. Protests erupt. The administration threatens to invoke the Insurrection Act and simultaneously announces it will cut funding to cities that don't cooperate with its enforcement agenda. The method is familiar: create crisis, demand submission, punish resistance.

This isn't about immigration policy. This is about whether the federal government can commandeer state and local governments through financial coercion.

## The Constitutional Architecture

The Founders designed a system of dual sovereignty. James Madison explained it clearly in Federalist 45: "The powers delegated by the proposed Constitution to the federal government are few and defined. Those which are to remain in the State governments are numerous and indefinite."

That division wasn't accidental. It was structural, deliberate, essential. The federal government enforces immigration law. States and cities run their own police departments, make their own public safety decisions, answer to their own voters. The Constitution does not permit Washington to conscript local law enforcement into federal service, nor to punish states financially for declining to assist.

Courts have repeatedly affirmed this principle. In Printz v. United States (1997), the Supreme Court struck down federal attempts to commandeer state officers. The anti-commandeering doctrine holds that Congress cannot compel states to enforce federal law. The logic is simple: if Washington could force states to implement federal policy, the division of sovereignty would collapse. States would become administrative units, not sovereign governments.

The spending power cases are equally clear. South Dakota v. Dole (1987) established that Congress can attach conditions to federal funding, but those conditions must relate to the purpose of the funds and cannot be so coercive that they amount to compulsion. In NFIB v. Sebelius (2012), the Court found that threatening to withhold all Medicaid funding unless states expanded the program crossed the line into unconstitutional coercion.

Judge William Orrick's ruling blocking the Trump administration's sanctuary city funding threats follows directly from this precedent. The federal government cannot use money as a cudgel to force states to abandon their own policies. That's not federalism. That's subjugation.

## Why Local Cooperation Matters

The administration's frustration is understandable on operational grounds. ICE operated more efficiently when it could pick up individuals already in custody at local jails. Detainer requests—federal holds on individuals about to be released from local custody—streamlined the process.

But efficiency isn't a constitutional argument.

Local jurisdictions adopted sanctuary policies for reasons rooted in their own governance responsibilities. Police chiefs and mayors argued that cooperation with federal immigration enforcement undermined community trust, making immigrant communities reluctant to report crimes or cooperate with investigations. They concluded that their public safety mission required them to separate local policing from federal immigration enforcement.

Those are legitimate policy judgments. Citizens can disagree with them, can vote officials out who make them, can change state law to require cooperation. What citizens cannot do—what the federal government cannot do—is override state sovereignty through financial threats.

The administration's response reveals the deeper problem. When state and local governments make decisions Washington dislikes, the federal playbook increasingly involves federal occupation (surge operations), federal prosecution (investigations of governors and mayors), and federal coercion (funding threats). Each step moves power from diffused to centralized, from accountable to distant, from constitutional order to executive will.

## The Pattern That Should Concern Us

I've seen this pattern before. An administration identifies a problem. Congress won't or can't act. The executive branch finds authorities—some legitimate, some stretched, some simply asserted—to act unilaterally. Opposition is framed as obstruction. Cooperation is demanded. Resistance is punished.

The mechanisms vary but the trajectory is consistent: concentration of power, erosion of limitations, normalization of the extraordinary.

Consider what's happening simultaneously in Minnesota:

- Federal agents deploying tear gas against protesters - A Justice Department investigation of state and local officials - Threats to invoke the Insurrection Act - Promises to cut federal funding - Military personnel operating alongside civilian law enforcement

Each element, taken alone, might have a technical legal justification. Collectively, they represent something else: a demonstration of federal dominance, a warning to other jurisdictions, a redefinition of the relationship between Washington and everywhere else.

This is how federalism dies—not in a single dramatic breach, but through accumulated pressure, through crises real and manufactured, through the transformation of cooperation into compulsion.

## The Question We Should Be Asking

The debate has focused on immigration enforcement and sanctuary policies. Those are important questions. But they're not the fundamental question.

The fundamental question is this: Can the federal government force state and local governments to implement federal policy by threatening their financial survival?

If the answer is yes, then federalism is dead. State sovereignty becomes administrative convenience. Local control becomes federal permission. The constitutional architecture collapses into a unitary system with power flowing in one direction—downward from Washington.

The Founders understood this danger. Hamilton warned in Federalist 17 that the states would be "constituent and essential parts of the federal government" whose independence must be preserved. Madison argued in Federalist 46 that state governments could "effectually oppose" federal overreach through "a refusal to cooperate with officers of the Union."

That's not obstruction. That's constitutional design working as intended.

When Washington attempts to override state resistance through funding coercion, it's not enforcing the law. It's rewriting the constitutional settlement, replacing dual sovereignty with federal supremacy, replacing political accountability with administrative compliance.

## What This Means

Courts will sort out the immediate legal questions. Judges have already blocked similar funding threats. They likely will again. The anti-commandeering doctrine and the spending power limitations are well-established. The administration will lose these cases, just as it did in the first term.

But that misses the point.

The point is that we're normalizing these confrontations, accepting as routine the deployment of federal force into cities over policy disputes, treating as ordinary the threat to cut funding whenever states decline to cooperate. We're moving from federalism as structure to federalism as discretion, from constitutional limits as binding to constitutional limits as negotiable.

I've sworn an oath to the Constitution enough times to know what it means. It means that powers not granted to the federal government remain with the states. It means that the federal government cannot compel state officers to enforce federal law. It means that spending power has limits. It means that federalism isn't just a theory—it's the architecture that makes self-government possible across a diverse republic.

When that architecture erodes, we don't just lose efficiency or clarity. We lose the structural protection that keeps power from accumulating in a single place, that maintains multiple centers of authority, that preserves space for local democracy and political difference.

The question isn't whether you support sanctuary policies or immigration enforcement. The question is whether you believe the Constitution means what it says about the limits of federal power. The question is whether dual sovereignty still matters, or whether we're willing to trade it for the efficiency of centralized control.

That question, unanswered, is why this matters.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Trade Becomes Coercion
pending.content:
I served in uniform. I served in government. I have sat in rooms where policy becomes action, where words on paper become orders that people follow. So I know what it looks like when power stops being bounded by law and starts being bounded only by will.

What happened Saturday is not a trade policy dispute.

It is the use of economic coercion against treaty allies to compel the transfer of sovereign territory.

President Trump announced a 10% tariff on eight NATO members, Denmark, Norway, Sweden, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, and Finland, effective February 1, escalating to 25% by June 1 if they do not facilitate "the Complete and Total purchase of Greenland" by the United States. Not negotiate. Not discuss. Purchase. As if an autonomous territory of 56,000 people, part of a democratic ally since the founding of NATO, were a warehouse property available for hostile takeover.

This is not about Greenland's strategic value. It is about whether an American president can weaponize the U.S. economy to dissolve the territorial integrity of allied democracies.

**What Changed Without Announcement**

Tariffs are a tool of trade policy. They address unfair practices, protect domestic industries, respond to economic injury. They operate within a framework of law: statutes, treaties, administrative procedures, judicial review.

This is something else.

These are not tariffs to address dumping or subsidies or market access. They are penalties imposed on allies for the offense of refusing to sell their land. The legal mechanism Trump would likely invoke, the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, requires an "unusual and extraordinary threat" to national security. The threat here is that European nations will not surrender Greenland.

If that becomes the standard for economic emergency powers, then emergency powers have no limiting principle.

If a president can declare any diplomatic impasse a national emergency and unilaterally impose escalating penalties until compliance, then the entire architecture of alliance diplomacy collapses into unilateral will. The question is not whether Trump has the statutory language to attempt this. The question is whether that language was ever meant to authorize what he is attempting.

Congress wrote emergency powers laws after Watergate specifically to constrain unilateral executive action. Section 1701 of IEEPA permits economic measures during a declared national emergency, but the declaration must identify an actual threat, not merely an unmet demand. Tariffs under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act require a finding that imports threaten national security, not that allies insufficiently defer.

The law exists. But the law's meaning shifts when its invocation becomes routine, when every refusal becomes a threat, when "emergency" describes any inconvenient constraint on executive preference.

**The Alliance Question**

NATO is not a treaty of convenience. It is a mutual defense pact rooted in Article 5: an attack on one is an attack on all. It has held through the Berlin Airlift, the Cuban Missile Crisis, the Balkan wars, September 11. Denmark, Norway, the UK, France, Germany, all of them, have sent their people to fight alongside ours under that covenant.

Now the United States is threatening them with economic punishment for declining to cede sovereign territory.

Senator Chris Coons stood in Copenhagen and said, "If we do things that cause Danes to question whether we can be counted on as a NATO ally, why would any other country seek to be our ally or believe in our representations?"

That is the question.

Alliances are built on reliability. When reliability is replaced by ultimatum, when partnership becomes subordination, when "ally" means "complies," then alliance becomes something else. It becomes hierarchy enforced by coercion. And hierarchies built on coercion do not endure.

Denmark has been our ally for 77 years. It hosts U.S. forces at Thule Air Base in Greenland. It has committed troops to every major NATO operation. It has stood with us when standing cost blood. And now we are imposing trade penalties because it will not sell us Greenland.

If that is how we treat Denmark, what does Poland believe? What does Estonia believe? What does any smaller ally believe about what America's word is worth?

**The Question of Law**

It is unclear, legally, how Trump intends to do this. Tariffs under existing statutory authority require specific findings, agency process, often congressional notification. The president cannot simply tweet a 10% penalty into existence. But the larger question is whether the legal framework itself still operates as a constraint or merely as a formality to be cited post hoc.

James Madison wrote in Federalist 47, "The accumulation of all powers, legislative, executive, and judiciary, in the same hands... may justly be pronounced the very definition of tyranny." The separation of powers exists not to slow government but to prevent exactly this: the conversion of law into the instrument of unilateral will.

Emergency powers laws were designed to permit swift action in genuine crises, not to bypass Congress whenever diplomacy requires patience. The question is not whether a president has emergency authority. The question is whether that authority extends to creating the emergency it purports to address, to declaring any frustration a crisis, any refusal a threat.

If it does, then Congress no longer legislates trade policy. It merely observes while the executive does.

**What This Normalizes**

In 2018, Trump imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, citing national security under Section 232. Allies objected. Courts mostly deferred. The precedent held: national security is whatever the president says it is, reviewable only at the margins.

In 2019, he threatened tariffs on Mexico to force immigration enforcement changes. Mexico complied. The lesson: economic coercion works when the target is weaker.

Now he is applying that lesson to NATO allies, demanding not policy changes but territorial concessions, using trade as the lever. Each escalation builds on the last. Each instance that goes unchallenged becomes the baseline for the next.

This is how norms erode. Not through dramatic constitutional collapse, but through incremental expansion, each step slightly beyond the last, each justified by precedent that itself was justified by convenience. The trade war becomes the diplomatic ultimatum becomes the demand for sovereign territory enforced by escalating economic penalties.

The question is not whether this violates a specific statute. The question is whether this is compatible with a government of laws.

**What Citizens Should Ask**

Not: Do we want Greenland for strategic reasons?

But: Do we want a presidency that can unilaterally coerce territorial concessions from allied democracies using emergency economic powers?

Not: Are tariffs an effective tool?

But: Are tariffs meant to enforce diplomatic demands that have nothing to do with trade?

Not: Is this technically legal?

But: Does law still constrain executive action, or does it merely describe what the president chooses to do?

These are different questions. They go to structure, not policy. They ask whether power is still accountable to something beyond itself.

**The Precedent**

In 1803, Thomas Jefferson bought Louisiana from France. It was a negotiated purchase between willing parties, ratified by treaty, approved by the Senate. The Constitution did not explicitly authorize it, and Jefferson himself had doubts, but it proceeded through legal process.

In 1867, William Seward bought Alaska from Russia. Again, a negotiated treaty, Senate ratification, legal appropriation.

In 1917, the U.S. purchased the Virgin Islands from Denmark. Treaty. Senate consent. Process.

Territorial acquisition has always been exceptional, conducted through law, requiring consent at every level: the selling nation, the Senate, the appropriating Congress. It has never been imposed by presidential ultimatum enforced through unilateral economic penalties.

Until now. If this proceeds.

**The Test**

Thousands marched in Copenhagen and Nuuk on Saturday, holding signs that read "Greenland is not for sale" and "Hands off." They were not protesting American strategic interests. They were asserting self-governance. They were reminding the world that people are not property, that sovereignty is not a transaction.

A Danish major general confirmed that Danish soldiers, if attacked on Danish soil, have the legal obligation to fight back. Even, presumably, if the attack comes from an ally.

That is where this leads. Not to war, probably, but to the question of whether war is even conceivable, whether the bonds that held for 77 years still mean what they once did.

The test is not whether Trump can find statutory language to justify tariffs. The test is whether the American constitutional system permits a president to use economic warfare to coerce territorial concessions from treaty allies, and whether Congress and the courts will allow it.

The test is whether law still limits power, or whether power now defines law.

That is the question this moment asks. And the answer will tell us what we still are.

pending.headline: The Law of Power
pending.content:
The UN Secretary-General said something remarkable last week. Not remarkable because it was untrue. Remarkable because it was said aloud.

"There are those that believe the power of law should be replaced by the law of power."

António Guterres was describing American foreign policy. He could have been describing a principle older than the Republic.

I spent years in uniform defending what we called the rules-based international order. That phrase carried weight in briefing rooms and treaty negotiations. It meant something specific: that nations, including powerful ones, would bind themselves to shared rules rather than act solely on interest and capability.

The question now is whether that binding was ever real, or whether it was a temporary arrangement of convenience that lasted only as long as American power was uncontested and American interests aligned with the appearance of law.

This isn't about whether the UN is effective. It isn't about whether international institutions need reform. It's about whether the United States remains a nation that believes law constrains power, or whether we have decided that our power defines what law means.

**What We Agreed To**

The United States drafted much of the UN Charter. American diplomats, shaped by two world wars, built the architecture of international law precisely to prevent powerful nations from acting with impunity.

Article 2(4) of the Charter prohibits "the threat or use of force against the territorial integrity or political independence of any state." The United States signed that treaty. The Senate ratified it. Under Article VI of the Constitution, it became "the supreme Law of the Land."

Not a suggestion. Not an aspiration. Law.

When we helped write those rules in 1945, we understood something essential: that unchecked power, even our own, would eventually become a threat to liberty everywhere. That binding ourselves to law, even when inconvenient, was the price of maintaining a world where smaller nations had any protection at all.

The alternative was the world we had just fought to end. The world where might made right and treaties were worth less than the paper they were printed on.

We chose differently then.

**The Drift**

I served in government when phrases like "kinetic military action" replaced "war" in official documents. When "enhanced interrogation" replaced "torture." When legal memos stretched definitions until they meant their opposite.

The pattern was always the same: Find a way to do what power wanted, then construct a legal justification afterward. Not "Is this lawful?" but "How can we make this appear lawful?"

That's not law. That's power wearing law's uniform.

Guterres described what anyone watching American foreign policy can see: a nation that considers multilateral solutions irrelevant, that acts first and consults allies later, if at all. A nation that speaks of sovereignty and international law when they serve our interests, and dismisses them when they don't.

The recent strike in Venezuela. The seizure of its president. The threats to annex Greenland, a territory of a NATO ally.

These aren't legal arguments. They're demonstrations of capability.

**The Constitutional Question**

The Founders designed a government that could not easily make war. They split the war power deliberately, giving Congress the authority to declare war and the President the authority to command forces once war was declared.

They did this because they had lived under unchecked executive power. They knew what it became.

"The constitution supposes, what the History of all Governments demonstrates, that the Executive is the branch of power most interested in war, and most prone to it," James Madison wrote. "It has accordingly with studied care vested the question of war to the Legislature."

Yet we have not formally declared war since 1942. We have fought wars in Korea, Vietnam, Iraq, Afghanistan, Syria, Libya, and elsewhere under various authorizations, resolutions, and executive determinations that bear little resemblance to the constitutional process the Founders mandated.

This didn't happen overnight. It happened through accumulation. Through precedent built on precedent, each one citing the last. Through emergency powers that never expired and legal interpretations that never faced serious challenge.

The line didn't move all at once. It drifted.

**What Allies See**

I remember what it meant to represent the United States overseas. To speak about human rights and rule of law with the authority of a nation that, however imperfectly, tried to live by those principles.

That authority came from restraint as much as strength. From the times we could have acted on power alone but chose to work through law instead. From the credibility of being bound by the same rules we asked others to follow.

Allies trusted us not because we were powerful, but because our power was, most of the time, predictable and constrained by institutions they could understand.

When the Secretary-General of the UN describes American policy as a rejection of multilateralism and international law, he is telling us what our allies already know and what our adversaries have long claimed: that we consider ourselves exempt from the constraints we demand others accept.

That is a different kind of power. It is also a different kind of isolation.

**The Normalization**

What concerns me most is not any single action. It's the quiet acceptance of a principle that would have alarmed the Founders: that American power, because it is power, operates in a different category than law.

This principle doesn't announce itself. It accretes through practice. Through the assumption that what we can do, we may do. Through the absence of accountability when power is misused. Through the bipartisan consensus that executive authority in foreign affairs is essentially unchecked.

It becomes normal to strike other nations without congressional authorization. Normal to detain people indefinitely without trial. Normal to invoke national security to avoid judicial review. Normal to treat international law as advisory.

The extraordinary becomes ordinary. The emergency becomes permanent. The exception becomes the rule.

This is how republics change. Not through dramatic breaks, but through the steady erosion of constraints that once seemed essential.

**The Test**

I don't know if the rules-based international order can be salvaged. I don't know if institutions designed for 1945 can address 2025's challenges. I don't know if multilateral solutions can solve problems that unilateral power cannot.

But I know this: A nation that believes its power places it above law is no longer constrained by law.

That includes the law that constrains its power at home.

The principle that power defines law doesn't stop at the border. If we are exempt from international law because we are powerful, why should the powerful within our own system be constrained by domestic law?

The logic is the same. The justification is the same. Only the scale differs.

The Founders understood something we risk forgetting: that unchecked power, even when wielded with good intentions, even when exercised by people we trust, eventually becomes a threat to liberty itself.

They built a system designed to prevent that. A system where law constrained power, where institutions checked ambition, where no person or branch could act without accountability.

That system didn't fail. We stopped maintaining it.

The question isn't whether the UN can reform itself. The question is whether the American people still believe that law should constrain power, or whether we have decided that our power is its own justification.

That question, unanswered, is why this still matters.

In Union there is Strength.
