pending.headline: When Sovereignty Becomes Negotiable
pending.content:
The President of the United States has announced that he will impose tariffs on eight NATO allies, including the United Kingdom, unless Denmark agrees to sell Greenland to Washington.

Read that again.

Not tariffs based on trade imbalances. Not tariffs as leverage in a security negotiation. Tariffs as the price for refusing to surrender sovereign territory.

When asked if he would rule out using military force to take Greenland, the President replied: "No comment."

This is not about Greenland's strategic value. This is about whether territorial integrity is still a principle that governs relations between free nations, or merely a preference that can be coerced away through economic threats.

**The Mechanism Matters**

I have served in government. I understand that nations pursue strategic interests. The United States has legitimate security concerns in the Arctic. Greenland's location matters to continental defense.

But how a nation pursues those interests reveals what kind of nation it is.

The President frames this as about "National and World Security." That framing does important work. It suggests that opposition to the demand is not merely unwise but dangerous, not merely disagreement but dereliction.

Notice what has disappeared from the conversation: any reference to the consent of the governed.

Greenland is home to 56,000 people. They are not a commodity to be purchased. They possess the right to self-determination under international law, recognized in the UN Charter, Article 1. Their premier has stated clearly: "We are not for sale."

That should end the discussion in any framework where popular sovereignty matters.

It has not ended the discussion.

**When Alliances Become Conditional**

The tariff threat targets eight nations. All are NATO members. All are democracies. All stood with the United States after September 11th under Article 5, the mutual defense clause that declares an attack on one is an attack on all.

Denmark lost 43 soldiers in Afghanistan fighting alongside American forces. Norway lost 10. The United Kingdom lost 457.

They did not die protecting trade advantages. They died because we invoked a treaty that says democracies defend each other.

Now that treaty obligation is being made conditional on compliance with a territorial demand.

The Danish foreign minister stated it plainly: "You can't threaten your way to ownership of Greenland."

That is not rhetoric. That is a statement about what separates law-governed nations from those where power is the only currency that matters.

If sovereignty is negotiable when a stronger power demands it, then every treaty is merely a pause between coercions. Every border is temporary. Every alliance lasts only as long as the stronger party finds it convenient.

**The Normalization**

This is not the first time extraordinary measures have been proposed in the name of security. The question is whether they become ordinary.

In 2002, the Authorization for Use of Military Force passed Congress to target those responsible for 9/11. It has since been invoked to justify military action in 18 countries, against groups that did not exist in 2001, without further congressional authorization.

In 2008, the Treasury Department received emergency authority to stabilize the financial system. The Troubled Asset Relief Program was sold as temporary and extraordinary. Elements of that emergency authority have been extended and renewed for 15 years.

Extraordinary becomes normal when we stop asking whether the initial justification still applies.

The President's demand is framed as imperative security policy. But security for whom? Greenland already hosts Pituffik Space Base, operated jointly by the United States and Denmark under treaty. NORAD conducts routine operations there with Danish cooperation.

The strategic access already exists. What is being demanded is not access but ownership.

**What Citizens Should Ask**

The question is not whether Greenland has strategic value.

The question is whether the United States can use economic coercion to force a democratic ally to surrender sovereign territory.

If the answer is yes, then what principle constrains that power? If tariffs can be imposed until Denmark yields Greenland, can they be imposed until Norway yields Svalbard? Until Canada yields the Northwest Passage?

Once sovereignty becomes negotiable through economic threat, what border is secure?

The President has also stated he will not rule out military force. When pressed, he said "no comment." That is not the same as saying no.

In 1939, Germany demanded that Poland cede the Free City of Danzig and grant extraterritorial access through the Polish Corridor. The demand was framed as addressing legitimate security concerns and correcting historical injustices. Poland refused. War followed.

I am not predicting war. I am noting that territorial demands backed by threats have a history. That history does not end well.

**The Test of Principle**

The United States was founded on the proposition that governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed. That principle is not merely domestic. It is the basis of the international order we built after 1945.

That order has flaws. It has failed often. But it rests on the idea that nations do not simply take what they can, that borders are not merely facts of power, that sovereignty matters.

If we abandon that principle when it becomes inconvenient, we abandon the only framework that prevents international relations from becoming purely a question of force.

The European Union's foreign policy chief said it clearly: "Sovereignty is not for trade."

That is not defiance. That is a statement of the principle that makes peaceful coexistence possible.

When the President imposes these tariffs on February 1st, as he has promised "100%" he will do, the question will not be whether European economies suffer. The question will be whether economic coercion in pursuit of territorial demands has become an acceptable tool of American statecraft.

If it has, then we are no longer the nation that wrote the Atlantic Charter or designed the United Nations. We are something else.

The test is not whether we can take Greenland. The test is whether we believe that power alone decides what is ours.

That question, still unanswered, is why this moment matters.

pending.headline: When the President Decides What "Cause" Means
pending.content:
I spent years in government service. I learned early that certain institutions exist not to make governing easier, but to make it harder in specific, necessary ways.

The Federal Reserve is one of those institutions.

Congress created it in 1913 after watching how politics and money interact when no barrier stands between them. The pattern was consistent: financial panics in the 1890s, political pressure for easy credit, economic collapse, repeat. The lesson was not complicated. When presidents can manipulate monetary policy for short-term political gain, the economy destabilizes in predictable ways.

So Congress built a wall. Not an absolute wall, but a procedural one. Federal Reserve governors serve fixed terms. They can be removed for malfeasance, but not for disagreement. Not for setting interest rates the president dislikes. Not for pursuing policies that serve long-term stability over short-term popularity.

That wall has held for 112 years.

This week, the Supreme Court considers whether to demolish it.

## The Argument Being Made

The legal question appears narrow. President Trump seeks to fire Lisa Cook, a Fed governor appointed by President Biden. The stated cause: irregularities in mortgage applications for two properties. Cook denies wrongdoing. Her lawyers note that four Cabinet members and the deputy attorney general have made similar applications without prosecution. The official who raised the allegations, Bill Pulte, has relatives who did the same.

But the narrow question hides a structural claim.

The administration argues that once the president determines cause exists, that determination is unreviewable by courts. The president's judgment is final. No independent tribunal examines the evidence. No standard of proof applies. If the president says cause exists, cause exists.

This is not about Lisa Cook's mortgages.

This is about whether "for cause" means anything at all.

I have seen this move before, in different contexts. A legal protection remains on paper while its meaning gets hollowed out. The words stay the same. The substance vanishes. You still need "cause" to fire a Fed governor, technically. But cause becomes whatever the president says it is, whenever he says it, without review.

That is not a protection. That is permission.

## What Powell Said

Jerome Powell, the Fed chair Trump himself appointed in 2018, is known for careful language and institutional deference. He avoided confrontation even as Trump publicly called him incompetent or crooked. He stayed quiet when the administration opened a criminal investigation into his Senate testimony about building renovations.

Then Powell spoke clearly.

"This new threat is not about my testimony last June or about the renovation of federal reserve buildings. Those are pretexts. The threat of criminal charges is a consequence of the Federal Reserve setting interest rates based on our best assessment of what will serve the public rather than following the preferences of the president."

Powell used the word "pretexts." That is the language of someone who has watched procedure become theater, who has seen legal mechanisms deployed not for their stated purpose but to achieve a different end.

He is describing what happens when the question is not whether cause exists, but whether claiming cause is sufficient.

## Why Congress Built the Wall

The argument for presidential control has constitutional weight. Article II vests executive power in the president. Proponents argue he cannot execute that power if he cannot remove officials who resist his direction.

But Congress has constitutional power too. Article I grants it authority to structure how government operates, including creating institutions that check executive discretion. The first Congress, which included many Founders, created the First Bank of the United States in 1791 with term-limited leadership precisely to insulate financial policy from direct presidential control.

They had watched how monarchs manipulate currency. They understood that elected executives face the same temptations.

The question is not whether the president has executive power. The question is whether that power extends to controlling monetary policy through personnel removal, when Congress specifically designed an institution to prevent that control.

Daniel Tarullo, a former Fed governor and Harvard law professor, explains the economic reality: "Presidents of both parties always want interest rates to go down, particularly in election years, but that inevitably destabilizes the economy."

When long-term rates rise because markets fear inflation, mortgages and business investment suffer. The political incentive is always for short-term stimulus. The economic necessity is often for long-term restraint. Congress created the Fed to resolve that tension by removing the decision from political calculation.

If the president can fire Fed governors who resist his preferences, that resolution fails. The Fed becomes what it was designed not to be: an instrument of presidential economic policy.

## The Normalization Pattern

I am watching a familiar pattern unfold.

First, you claim emergency authority for extraordinary circumstances. Then you find ordinary circumstances that arguably fit the emergency framework. Then the framework becomes routine. Then the exception becomes the rule.

The administration is not arguing it can fire Fed governors at will. It is arguing it can fire them for cause, and that presidential determination of cause is unreviewable.

But unreviewable determination is functionally equivalent to at-will removal. If I can fire you whenever I decide sufficient cause exists, and no one can challenge that decision, then I can fire you whenever I want. The "for cause" requirement becomes a formality, a box to check, not a constraint on power.

Every living Fed chair except Powell has signed briefs opposing this change. Treasury secretaries from both parties have too. So have prominent economists across the political spectrum. Jamie Dimon, not known for alarmism, warns of "reverse consequences" including higher inflation and increased borrowing costs.

These are not partisans defending bureaucratic turf. These are people who understand what happens when short-term political pressure drives monetary policy.

## What the Court Said Before

The Supreme Court, in recent emergency docket rulings, allowed Trump to remove other agency heads with term protections. But in one opinion, the conservative majority noted the Fed is different: "a uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States."

That distinction recognizes something important. Some institutions exist not to implement presidential policy but to constrain it. They are countermajoritarian by design, built to resist immediate political pressure in service of longer-term stability.

The question before the Court is whether that distinction still holds. Whether the constitutional structure allows Congress to create institutions genuinely independent of direct presidential control, or whether Article II executive power ultimately subsumes everything.

## The Question Citizens Should Ask

This is not about whether Lisa Cook should be a Fed governor. This is not about whether Trump's economic policy preferences are sound. This is not even about whether the Federal Reserve as currently structured is the best possible design.

This is about whether presidential power over monetary policy has effective limits.

If the president can remove Fed governors by claiming cause and that claim is unreviewable, then future presidents inherit that power. A president who wants higher interest rates to fight inflation can fire governors who resist. A president who wants lower rates to stimulate growth can fire governors who disagree. The Fed becomes responsive to whoever holds office, not to any consistent standard or statutory mandate.

The wall Congress built in 1913 was not meant to last forever unchanged. But it was meant to be removed deliberately, through legislation, not eroded through interpretations that preserve the form while eliminating the substance.

I am not arguing the president should never be able to remove Federal Reserve governors. I am arguing that if we change that 112-year-old protection, we should change it knowingly, through democratic process, not through legal claims that redefine "cause" until it means "disagreement."

Paul Clement, who served as solicitor general under George W. Bush, is arguing this case for Cook and the Fed's independence. Powell himself will be in the courtroom. That tells you something about what people who have served, across administrations, understand about what is at stake.

The question is not whether the president wants compliant officials. Every president does.

The question is whether monetary policy should be insulated from that desire, and whether Congress has authority to create that insulation.

The answer to that question shapes whether we have independent institutions, or whether we have institutions that answer to whoever currently holds power.

That question, framed clearly, is why this moment matters.

pending.headline: What Happens When the System Assumes Good Faith
pending.content:
I served in the uniformed services. I worked in government agencies where oversight existed, where inspectors general mattered, where the line between the White House and prosecutorial power was not crossed because it could not be crossed without consequences.

That line has now been crossed. Repeatedly. Openly.

The NPR report catalogs what has happened in one year. The catalog itself is the problem. When you need a multi-section graphic essay to track the erosion of constitutional norms, you are no longer talking about policy disputes. You are talking about a different kind of government.

This is not about partisan alignment. This is about whether the system designed in Philadelphia in 1787 can withstand a presidency that treats its constraints as suggestions.

## The Architecture Assumed Restraint

The Constitution did not anticipate a president who would fire inspectors general for doing their jobs. It did not envision a Justice Department weaponized against political opponents while the president announces his targets on social media. It did not plan for congressional majorities that would watch the executive branch seize spending authority, implement sweeping tariffs without meaningful legislative debate, and respond with silence.

The Founders built a system of checks and balances. What they assumed, but could not guarantee, was that people in power would fear violating those checks.

That fear is gone.

When a president pardons those convicted of violently attacking the Capitol, he is not merely exercising constitutional authority. He is declaring that political loyalty supersedes the rule of law. When his administration defies court orders, intimidates journalists, and threatens prosecutors who investigate allies, he is testing whether the system will enforce its own rules.

So far, the answer has been equivocal.

## Normalization Is the Danger

What makes this moment dangerous is not any single act. It is the speed at which the extraordinary becomes ordinary.

A year ago, the idea that the president would openly direct prosecutions of political enemies would have been unthinkable. Now it is reported as fact, cataloged alongside other actions, and the news cycle moves on.

A year ago, the systematic dismantling of public health institutions based on a cabinet secretary's personal theories would have triggered congressional investigations. Now it is policy.

A year ago, Congress would not have tolerated the executive branch unilaterally withholding appropriated funds. Now it happens, and the legislative branch shrugs.

This is how republics slip. Not through a single coup. Through a thousand small adjustments in what is considered acceptable. Through the quiet recalibration of what "checks and balances" means until it means very little at all.

## The Founders Warned Us

Madison wrote in Federalist 51: "If men were angels, no government would be necessary. If angels were to govern men, neither external nor internal controls on government would be necessary."

The system was designed for people who would seek power and misuse it. What the Founders could not fully account for was a scenario where one branch of government would actively assist another in dismantling the controls meant to restrain them both.

The question is not whether President Trump is popular with his base. The question is whether popularity justifies the systematic elimination of accountability mechanisms.

Lincoln faced a genuine existential crisis, a civil war that threatened the nation's survival. Even then, he submitted to judicial review, accepted the legitimacy of elections during wartime, and defended the principle that no president is above the law. His suspension of habeas corpus was contested in court, debated in Congress, and ultimately constrained.

What we face now is not a civil war. It is a claim that electoral victory grants authority to disregard institutional constraints whenever they prove inconvenient. That is not a muscular presidency. That is something else.

## The Test Is Here

The question citizens should be asking is this: What happens when the system designed to check power assumes that those in power will respect its legitimacy?

We are finding out.

Federal judges issue orders. The administration ignores them. Congress holds the purse. The executive branch withholds funds anyway. Inspectors general investigate. They are fired. Journalists report. They are threatened. Scientists provide data. They are silenced.

Each act alone might be debated on its merits. Taken together, they form a pattern. That pattern is not compatible with a government of laws.

The midterm elections will matter. Whether Congress reasserts its constitutional role will matter. Whether courts enforce their orders will matter. Whether citizens demand accountability will matter.

But what matters most is whether we recognize what is happening while it is happening. Whether we see the difference between legitimate policy disputes and the systematic dismantling of the mechanisms that make self-government possible.

The architecture of the republic is still standing. The question is whether anyone is still willing to defend it.

That question, unanswered, is why we must answer it now.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Foreign Aid Becomes Ideological Enforcement
pending.content:
I spent years in government watching how programs evolve. You draft them narrowly, sell them as temporary, assure everyone they're limited in scope. Then you expand them. Then expand them again. Then the expansion becomes the baseline, and anyone questioning it is told they're overreacting to normal policy.

That's what's happening here.

The Mexico City policy started in 1984 as a restriction on family planning funds, roughly $8 billion. By last week, it covered all non-military foreign assistance, over $30 billion. Now it extends beyond abortion to bar funding for organizations that "promote gender ideology" or embrace diversity, equity, and inclusion programs.

This isn't about abortion anymore. This is about using the federal purse to enforce ideological conformity on a global scale.

## The Mechanism of Control

The expansion works through financial coercion. Organizations abroad that want U.S. aid, whether for disaster relief, HIV treatment, maternal health, or emergency food distribution, must now pledge not to discuss abortion, not to provide gender-affirming care, not to implement DEI initiatives. The policy applies not just to NGOs but to multilateral organizations like U.N. agencies and, to some extent, foreign governments themselves.

Consider the operational reality. An organization in Uganda runs a cervical cancer screening program. It also provides contraception counseling that includes discussion of all options. Under the new policy, it must choose: stop counseling women about abortion, or lose funding for cancer screening.

A clinic in Madagascar provides maternal health care in rural areas where no other services exist. It also treats transgender patients. Now it must decide whether treating those patients is worth losing the ability to provide prenatal care to hundreds of women.

That's not protecting life. That's leveraging desperation.

## The Constitutional Question

The executive branch has broad authority over foreign policy and foreign aid distribution. No one disputes that.

But this policy raises a question that goes beyond legal authority to constitutional principle: Should the executive branch use appropriated funds to impose ideological tests on speech and association, even abroad?

Congress appropriates money for specific purposes, public health, disaster relief, humanitarian assistance. The executive branch now conditions that money not on effectiveness or accountability, but on compliance with an ideological framework that extends far beyond the stated purpose of the funds.

When disaster strikes and the most trusted, most effective local organization cannot respond because it also provides reproductive health counseling, that's not stewardship of taxpayer funds. That's subordinating humanitarian need to political agenda.

## The Pattern of Expansion

Watch how this works. First, you establish the principle with something many Americans support, restricting abortion funding. Then you expand to all global health funding. Then to all foreign assistance. Then you add restrictions on "gender ideology." Then DEI.

Each expansion is presented as minor, clarifying, merely ensuring taxpayer dollars don't fund things Americans oppose. But the cumulative effect is a global gag rule that reaches into maternal health, HIV treatment, emergency response, and now organizational hiring and internal policies.

Organizations will self-censor. They'll avoid serving populations, discussing topics, or implementing programs that might endanger funding. The chilling effect will extend far beyond what the policy explicitly prohibits.

That's how control works. You don't need to enforce every provision. You just need people to fear enforcement enough that they police themselves.

## The Precedent

In 1992, the Supreme Court held in *Rust v. Sullivan* that the government could prohibit family planning clinics receiving federal funds from discussing abortion. The decision was 5-4. Justice Blackmun, dissenting, warned about "viewpoint-based suppression of speech simply because it is carried out through the exercise of Congress's power of the purse."

He was describing exactly what is happening now, but on a global scale with far broader reach.

The question isn't whether the executive branch can attach conditions to foreign aid. It can. The question is whether those conditions can be used to suppress speech, dictate internal organizational policies, and enforce ideological conformity on matters unrelated to the purpose of the funding.

When aid for disaster relief is conditioned on not discussing abortion, when HIV treatment funding requires organizations to reject DEI principles, when maternal health programs must pledge not to counsel transgender patients, the conditions have become untethered from the purpose.

## What This Means for Accountability

Foreign aid should be accountable to outcomes. Are people being helped? Are funds being used effectively? Are programs achieving their stated goals?

This policy shifts accountability from results to ideology. It doesn't ask whether organizations are saving lives. It asks whether they're adhering to a particular political and social framework.

That shift matters. When government programs are evaluated on ideological compliance rather than effectiveness, the government loses the ability to distinguish between what works and what merely signals the right politics.

## The Question Citizens Should Ask

The question isn't whether you support abortion rights or oppose gender ideology. The question is whether executive power should be used to impose those positions globally through financial coercion, even when doing so undermines the stated purpose of the aid itself.

Should the United States condition hurricane relief on organizational policies about gender? Should it bar the most effective HIV prevention programs because they implement DEI training? Should it force foreign governments to choose between American aid and their own health priorities?

That's not foreign policy. That's ideological imperialism.

And the precedent it sets domestically is clear: if executive power can condition foreign aid on speech, association, and internal organizational policies abroad, why not domestic grants, contracts, and programs at home?

The expansion will continue. It always does. The mechanism is established, the principle accepted, the process normalized. Each new restriction will be presented as modest, reasonable, merely ensuring taxpayer dollars aren't misused.

Until one day we look up and realize that government funding, which touches nearly every institution in American life, comes with an ideological test.

That test, once established, doesn't go away when administrations change. It just changes direction.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Sovereign Nations Become Provinces
pending.content:
I watched this happen before.

Not the specific threat, not the exact trade dispute, but the pattern. A president declares that a neighboring democracy exists at his sufferance. That its trade relationships, its foreign policy, its very sovereignty are subject to approval from Washington. That 100% tariffs, economic devastation visited on millions, can be imposed by tweet if a allied government makes decisions we dislike.

The threat itself is extraordinary. The casualness is what matters.

President Trump has threatened Canada with punitive tariffs because its government negotiated a trade agreement with China. Not because Canada violated a treaty obligation to the United States. Not because Canada acted contrary to established trade law. But because Canada made a sovereign decision about its own economic policy that the president believes serves Chinese rather than American interests.

He calls Prime Minister Carney "Governor Carney."

That's not political theater. That's a statement of constitutional position.

## What Changed

Article I, Section 8 gives Congress the power "to regulate Commerce with foreign Nations." Article II makes the president commander-in-chief and gives him authority to make treaties "by and with the Advice and Consent of the Senate." Nowhere does the Constitution grant the executive unilateral authority to threaten economic warfare against treaty allies who exercise their own sovereignty.

The trade relationship in question involves the Canada-U.S.-Mexico Agreement (CUSMA/USMCA), which replaced NAFTA. That agreement is binding treaty law. It contains dispute resolution mechanisms. It has scheduled reviews. It was negotiated, signed, and ratified through constitutional process.

Trump is not proposing to invoke those mechanisms.

He is threatening unilateral action, outside treaty obligations, in response to a sovereign nation's independent trade policy. He is asserting, in effect, that Canada's freedom of action exists only to the extent that it pleases the United States. That Canadian sovereignty is provisional, subject to American approval.

The numbers make clear what's at stake. Nearly $3.6 billion in goods and services cross the border daily. Canada supplies 60% of U.S. crude oil imports, 85% of electricity imports, and critical minerals the Pentagon considers essential to national security. A 100% tariff would devastate both economies.

That devastation is the point. The threat is designed to compel submission.

## The Quiet Erosion

Hamilton warned about this in Federalist No. 75. Writing about treaty power, he noted that "the history of human conduct does not warrant that exalted opinion of human virtue which would make it wise in a nation to commit interests of so delicate and momentous a kind" to the sole discretion of one person. Treaties require Senate consent, he argued, because "the power of making treaties is plainly neither the one nor the other" of legislative or executive power alone, but something requiring both.

The Framers feared consolidation of authority in a single office. They designed separation of powers specifically to prevent one person from wielding the combined force of legislation, execution, and foreign policy without check or balance.

What we are witnessing is the assertion that emergency trade authority, temporary tariff powers granted by Congress in specific contexts, can be wielded as permanent instruments of presidential will to coerce allied democracies.

This is not about whether Canada's China deal serves American interests. Reasonable people can disagree about trade policy.

This is about whether the constitutional structure governing foreign commerce still functions. Whether treaty obligations bind. Whether Congress retains its Article I authority. Whether allies are sovereign or provincial.

## The Pattern Across Borders

Trump's threat to Canada comes while he publicly discusses annexing Greenland, absorbing Canada as a 51st state, and treating NATO allies as protectorates who exist at American discretion. At Davos, he declared "Canada lives because of the United States."

In one week, he praised Canada's China agreement, then threatened to destroy Canada's economy over it.

The inconsistency is not confusion. It is demonstration. The message is that policy, principle, and treaty obligation matter less than presidential prerogative. That allied governments must constantly calculate not what serves their interests or honors their agreements, but what mood they might encounter from Washington.

Prime Minister Carney responded by saying "Middle powers must act together because if you are not at the table, you are on the menu." That's the language of nations facing a predatory power, not the language of treaty allies within a constitutional system of law.

Canada hosts American military installations. Canadian and American forces are integrated through NORAD. The border is defended jointly. Intelligence is shared. For three-quarters of a century, the relationship has been grounded in mutual treaty obligations and constitutional process.

The president is asserting the right to set all that aside if a sovereign government makes a trade decision he dislikes.

## What the Constitution Says About This

Article VI declares that treaties are "the supreme Law of the Land." They bind the president as much as they bind Congress or the states. The CUSMA is not a guideline. It is law.

If Canada has violated that agreement, mechanisms exist to address it. If the agreement requires renegotiation, it comes up for review this year through the process specified in the treaty itself.

Trump is not proposing to use those mechanisms. He is threatening to ignore them. To treat binding treaty law as provisional, subject to his unilateral revision based on his assessment of Canadian policy toward third parties.

The precedent is devastating. If a president can threaten allied democracies with economic destruction for making sovereign policy choices, then treaty obligations mean nothing. Congressional authority over foreign commerce means nothing. The constitutional separation of powers means nothing.

All that remains is presidential discretion, unchecked by law or process.

## The Question No One Is Asking

Here is what matters: Can the president unilaterally threaten trade war against treaty allies who exercise sovereignty in ways he dislikes?

Not: Is Canada's China policy wise?

Not: Does Trump's threat serve American interests?

But: Does constitutional structure still constrain executive action, or has emergency authority become permanent power to coerce sovereign allies?

Because if the answer is that the president can do this, then we no longer have a constitutional foreign policy. We have imperial prerogative, exercised at presidential whim, bounded only by what the president believes he can accomplish.

Madison wrote in Federalist No. 47 that "the accumulation of all powers, legislative, executive, and judiciary, in the same hands, whether of one, a few, or many, and whether hereditary, self-appointed, or elective, may justly be pronounced the very definition of tyranny."

Canadians are now learning what Americans are learning: that constitutional constraint, treaty obligation, and separation of powers have become negotiable. That authority asserted as temporary has become permanent. That extraordinary measures are now routine.

The tariff threat may never be implemented. Trump may shift position again tomorrow. But the assertion has been made. The precedent is established. An allied democracy has been told its sovereignty exists at American sufferance.

That question, unanswered, is what makes this moment dangerous.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Federal Authority Meets a Camera
pending.content:
I spent years in government. I know what an after-action report looks like when officers use lethal force. I know what accountability looks like when federal agents operate on American streets.

What happened in Minneapolis on January 24, 2026 is not that.

## The Facts on Record

Alex Pretti, 37 years old, intensive care nurse, U.S. citizen, no criminal record, lawful carry permit.

Multiple videos show him holding a phone. Six federal officers tackle him. He's face down on the ground. Ten shots fired into his back.

Federal officials immediately called him a "domestic terrorist" planning to "massacre" officers.

The videos contradict that claim entirely.

## This Is Not About Immigration Enforcement

The issue here is not whether immigration law should be enforced. The issue is whether federal agents can kill an American citizen on a city street, contradict the video evidence with immediate accusations of terrorism, and then refuse to allow state investigators access to the scene.

That's not immigration enforcement. That's something else.

Deputy Attorney General Todd Blanche called it a "split-second decision" in a "complicated, violent situation." The commanding officer, Gregory Bovino, said "the victims are the Border Patrol agents."

The video shows Pretti helping someone up. Then he's tackled. Then he's shot in the back while pinned to the ground.

A federal judge had to issue an emergency restraining order to prevent the destruction of evidence. State investigators with a lawful search warrant were blocked from a public street by federal agents.

In a constitutional republic, when government uses lethal force, there is an investigation. There is accountability. There is transparency.

Not here.

## The Pattern Is the Problem

This is the second fatal shooting by immigration agents in Minneapolis this month. The first victim, Renee Macklin Good, was shot while turning her car to drive away. The Trump administration announced it will not investigate that killing either.

Between these two deaths: a 5-year-old detained, a U.S. citizen of Hmong descent dragged into his yard in his underwear at gunpoint without a warrant, legal residents swept up in what residents describe as an "arrest-first, ask-questions-later" approach.

Three thousand federal agents in Minneapolis. Five times the size of the city's police force. Operating under what authority, exactly? Subject to what oversight?

Governor Tim Walz said the federal government cannot be trusted to investigate itself in this case. A Republican senator, Bill Cassidy, broke with his party to call for a joint investigation. A former Trump administration DHS general counsel called for the president's impeachment over what he termed "lawlessness, fascism, and cruelty."

The Minnesota Gun Owners Caucus, a Second Amendment advocacy group, called for transparency. When gun rights advocates are questioning whether a man with a lawful carry permit can be shot for simply having that gun, something fundamental has shifted.

## The Constitutional Question

The Fourth Amendment protects against unreasonable searches and seizures. The Fifth Amendment guarantees due process. The Fourteenth applies those protections against state action.

When federal agents kill someone on a public street and refuse to allow a state with jurisdiction to investigate, when they immediately brand the victim a terrorist despite video evidence showing otherwise, when a federal judge must intervene to preserve evidence, we are watching constitutional protections collapse in real time.

This isn't a Republican issue or a Democratic issue. This is a republic issue.

Mayor Jacob Frey said it plainly: "The masked militarized force and unidentified agents patrolling our streets, that is what erodes trust in both law enforcement and in democracy itself."

He told residents their grandchildren would ask them what side they were on.

That's the right question, wrong verb tense.

Your grandchildren will ask you what you did when video evidence contradicted the government's immediate characterization of a citizen as a terrorist. When federal agents blocked state investigators from a scene. When emergency court orders were required to preserve evidence. When the Department of Justice stood by the shooting of a man face-down on the ground.

## What Accountability Looks Like

In a free society, when government kills someone, there is an investigation. Not by the same agency that employed the shooter, but by an independent authority with the power to charge if wrongdoing occurred.

That investigation considers the evidence. It does not begin with a conclusion that the victim was a "domestic terrorist."

If the use of force was justified, the evidence will show it. If it was not, there are consequences. That's not anti-law enforcement. That's pro-law enforcement. It's how officers who do their jobs right are distinguished from those who don't.

What we're seeing in Minneapolis is the opposite. Federal officials announced the victim's guilt immediately. They blocked state investigators. A court had to intervene to prevent evidence destruction.

That's not accountability. That's impunity.

## The Test

Here is the test for whether this should concern you, regardless of your views on immigration, on Trump, on any partisan consideration:

Would you accept this outcome if the political parties were reversed?

If a Democratic administration deployed 3,000 agents to a city, killed two citizens in a month, called them terrorists despite video evidence to the contrary, and refused to allow state investigation, would you consider that a legitimate exercise of federal authority?

If your answer changes based on who is president, you don't have principles. You have preferences.

The Constitution doesn't change with administrations. Due process doesn't depend on the party in power. The right to accountability when government uses lethal force doesn't belong to people you agree with politically. It belongs to everyone.

Alex Pretti was helping someone up when federal agents tackled him. He was face-down when they shot him. Ten rounds. In the back.

The government called him a terrorist before any investigation.

The video tells a different story.

A judge had to order agents not to destroy evidence.

This is where we are.

## In Union There Is Strength

Minneapolis activated its National Guard, not against a foreign threat but to protect residents from escalating tensions with federal agents in their own streets. Think about that.

Residents held vigils in subzero cold. "It can be anyone walking past this street right now," one told reporters. That's not hysteria. That's recognition.

When video evidence contradicts official accounts and officials maintain their version anyway, when courts must intervene to preserve evidence, when a former administration official calls what he witnessed "fascism," the question is not whether this is a problem.

The question is whether there will be accountability.

The Constitution provides mechanisms for that. State investigations. Federal courts. Congressional oversight. Public transparency.

All of those are being resisted.

That resistance is the story.

pending.headline: When Governments Wage War on Their Own People
pending.content:
I spent two decades in uniform, some of that time in places where governments turned their militaries inward. I learned to recognize certain patterns. The internet goes dark first. Then the official death counts stay suspiciously low. Then you start hearing numbers from people on the ground, and they don't match.

Six thousand one hundred and twenty-six people.

That's not a protest crackdown. That's a massacre.

The Human Rights Activists News Agency verified each death individually, working through networks inside Iran despite a comprehensive internet blackout now in its third week. The Iranian government claims 3,117 dead and calls the rest "terrorists." The disparity between those numbers isn't a rounding error. It's the space where accountability goes to die.

This started over currency collapse. Within days it became something larger, the kind of moment when a society asks whether it will continue to be governed by those who rule it. The theocracy answered with bullets. Over 41,800 people arrested. Eighty-six children dead. And an internet blackout so complete that families cannot call out, journalists cannot report in, and the world watches through the narrowest of windows.

The United States now positions an aircraft carrier group in the region. President Trump threatens military action if mass executions proceed. Iran's proxy militias signal willingness to fight. We stand at the edge of regional war, and the predicate is this: a government killing its own people in numbers that approach civil war casualties, all while the world debates whether to intervene.

But that debate misses the essential question.

## What Are We Witnessing?

This isn't about Trump or American military posture or regional proxy conflicts. This is about whether the international order has any remaining capacity to respond when a government treats peaceful protest as armed rebellion and answers it with industrial-scale violence.

The Iranian government has cut its population off from the world so thoroughly that we cannot even confirm the dead. Think about what that means. In 2026, with satellite technology and global telecommunications, a nation-state can create an informational black hole around mass killing. The blackout itself is the story—the demonstration that a government can act with such impunity that it need not even pretend to justify itself.

When I served overseas, we briefed on rules of engagement, on proportionality, on the laws of armed conflict. Those laws exist because certain principles transcend borders: you don't massacre civilians, you don't use military force against peaceful protest, you maintain some connection between the threat faced and the force applied. Iran's government has discarded all of that. The currency collapsed, people protested, and the response was to kill them by the thousands.

That's not law enforcement. That's war against a civilian population.

## The Mechanics of Impunity

The internet blackout is not incidental. It's the essential predicate to everything that follows. In a connected world, governments act differently when they know they're being watched. Remove that connectivity and you remove the external restraint. You create a space where violence can be applied without immediate consequence, where bodies can be buried before they're counted, where the official narrative has time to solidify before evidence emerges to contradict it.

Iran has done this before, but never at this scale or duration. The 2009 Green Movement, the 2019 protests over fuel prices—both saw internet disruptions and violent crackdowns. But this is different in degree and kind. Three weeks of near-total blackout. Death tolls approaching small-war levels. A government that has stopped even pretending to distinguish between peaceful protesters and armed insurgents.

The international architecture built after World War II was premised on the idea that sovereignty has limits, that governments cannot simply do as they please to their own populations, that the world community has some obligation to respond when mass atrocity occurs. We've watched that architecture erode for years. Now we're watching it fail in real time.

## The Dangerous Precedent

What concerns me most is not this crisis alone but what it establishes for the next one. Iran has demonstrated that in 2026, a government can kill thousands of its own people, cut them off from the world while doing it, and face no meaningful international response beyond diplomatic statements and the positioning of military assets that may or may not be used.

That's a lesson other governments will learn.

When a government can kill with this kind of impunity, when the international community proves unable or unwilling to respond except through the threat of external military force, we validate the proposition that internal sovereignty is absolute. That governments owe their people nothing. That the slaughter of civilians engaged in peaceful protest is a matter of domestic jurisdiction, regrettable perhaps but ultimately beyond the reach of international principle.

This is how norms collapse. Not through formal treaty revision or explicit policy change, but through accumulation of examples where the stated rules don't apply. Where governments kill and face no consequence. Where the international community deploys the vocabulary of human rights but not its mechanisms. Where the choice becomes either military intervention or watching in silence, with no middle ground of meaningful accountability.

## The Question No One Is Asking

Here's what troubles me: We're debating whether the United States should bomb Iran. We're tracking carrier groups and parsing militia statements and gaming out regional war scenarios. All of that matters. But we're not asking the question that actually determines what kind of world we live in.

Is there any international principle, any mechanism, any remaining norm that can respond to mass killing of civilians by their own government without requiring either military intervention or acquiescence?

Because if the answer is no, if our only options are war or silence, then we've already conceded that sovereignty means governments can do whatever they want to their own people. We've accepted that the international order has no capacity to defend human rights except through force of arms. We've validated the proposition that power without accountability is the natural state of nations.

That question, unanswered, determines everything that follows.

The Iranian people are dying in the dark, cut off from the world, their deaths undercounted by their government and barely witnessed by ours. The carrier group sails toward the region. The militias prepare. And we debate military intervention while the fundamental question remains unasked: What is sovereignty worth if it means governments can massacre their people with impunity?

I don't know if military action is justified here. I know that it's the wrong question if it's the only question. The test of our international order isn't whether we're willing to go to war over atrocity. It's whether we have any other answer when atrocity occurs.

Right now, we don't.

That silence, that absence of any mechanism between war and acquiescence, is what six thousand dead Iranians have revealed. The question isn't what America does next. The question is what a world looks like where this can happen and our only choices are bombs or nothing.

The test is here.

In Union there is Strength.

pending.headline: When Safety Standards Are Shared With Industry Before the Public
pending.content:
I spent years working in government facilities where nuclear materials were handled. The protocols were exhaustive. The documentation was redundant. The oversight was layered. And everyone understood why.

When you're working with materials that can kill people decades after exposure, when you're securing substances that terrorists would cross oceans to obtain, when you're protecting groundwater that millions depend on, you don't streamline safety. You make it burdensome on purpose.

The Department of Energy has now rewritten over 750 pages of nuclear safety requirements, reducing them to roughly one-third of their original length. The new rules were shared with the companies being regulated. They were not shared with the public.

That's the story.

But the constitutional question is different. It's about who gets to know what the government is doing, and when, and why.

## The Inversion of Accountability

In a constitutional republic, the government is accountable to the people. Regulatory agencies exist to protect public safety, not to serve as concierge services for industry. The public has a right to know the standards that will govern activities that could affect their health, their water, their land, their lives.

What happened here inverts that relationship.

The Department of Energy rewrote safety standards for experimental nuclear reactors. It briefed industry executives. It created "Concierge Teams" reporting directly to the Secretary of Energy to "ensure expeditious processing" of applications. It did all of this without publishing the new rules or seeking public comment.

The new orders were legally changed because DOE directives, unlike federal regulations, can be revised internally without public notice. That's technically permissible. But constitutional governance isn't only about what's technically legal. It's about maintaining the relationship between power and accountability that makes self-government possible.

When an agency shares new safety standards with the companies it regulates before sharing them with the public those companies might endanger, something has shifted. The question isn't whether DOE followed procedural rules. The question is: who is the government working for?

## What Was Cut, and What That Means

The specifics matter because they reveal the nature of what's being normalized.

Gone is the requirement to keep radiation exposure "As Low As Reasonably Achievable," a principle that has governed nuclear safety for decades at both DOE and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. The justification is economic efficiency. Workers can now receive higher doses before an investigation is triggered. Reactors can be built with less shielding. The financial burden is reduced.

Gone is the requirement to designate a Cognizant System Engineer for each critical safety system, someone responsible for understanding every part of a reactor that could cause a catastrophic failure.

Gone is the requirement to use "best available technology" to protect water supplies from radioactive discharge. The language was changed from "prohibited" to "should be avoided."

Gone are over 500 pages of security requirements, firearms training standards, limits on guard force working hours, specifications for physical barriers protecting nuclear material. They've been reduced to 23 pages of bullet points.

These aren't minor adjustments to outdated bureaucracy. These are foundational safety principles developed after Three Mile Island, after decades of nuclear accidents, after careful study of what happens when protocols fail. They were written in the language of mandatory compliance: "prohibited," "must," "shall." They have been rewritten in the language of discretion: "should be," "can be," "as appropriate."

That shift from mandate to suggestion is how regulatory authority quietly becomes regulatory suggestion.

## The Deadline That Explains Everything

On May 23, 2025, the President signed an executive order requiring the Department of Energy to approve at least three experimental nuclear reactors "with the goal of achieving criticality in each of the three reactors by July 4, 2026."

Fourteen months to review, approve, and oversee construction of multiple untested reactor designs.

A professor who ran DOE's Office of Nuclear Energy until 2024 called the timeline aggressive "to say the least." Research reactors typically take at least two years to build after construction begins. Few have ever been built on this timescale.

The deadline created the pressure. The pressure created the justification for speed. Speed created the justification for secrecy. And secrecy created the opportunity to rewrite safety standards away from public scrutiny.

This is how extraordinary measures become normalized. A symbolic deadline, a presidential signature, an industry eager to move fast, a regulatory structure that permits internal revision, and suddenly you have experimental reactors being built under safety standards the public hasn't seen.

The goal is innovation. The method is opacity. And once the reactors are operational under these standards, the standards themselves become precedent.

## The Question of Trust

Christopher Hanson, who chaired the Nuclear Regulatory Commission until he was fired by President Trump in 2025, said something worth considering: "I would argue that the Department of Energy relaxing its nuclear safety and security standards in secret is not the best way to engender the kind of public trust that's going to be needed for nuclear to succeed more broadly."

He's right, but he's understating the problem.

Public trust in nuclear power has been fragile since Three Mile Island. Every proposed reactor site faces organized opposition. Communities demand transparency, detailed safety reviews, environmental impact studies. They want to know what's being built, how it will be secured, what could go wrong, and who will be held accountable if it does.

The regulatory process, burdensome as it is, exists partly to create that trust. It forces agencies to explain themselves. It gives citizens the opportunity to ask questions, raise concerns, point out risks the experts might have missed. The slowness itself communicates seriousness.

Bypassing that process doesn't just risk safety failures. It guarantees trust failures. When people learn that experimental reactors are being built under secret safety standards, that the rules were shared with industry before the public, that a "Concierge Team" exists to speed applications through review, they will conclude that the government is working for someone else.

And they will be right to conclude it.

## What James Madison Would Recognize

Madison wrote in Federalist 51 that "the great security against a gradual concentration of the several powers in the same department, consists in giving to those who administer each department the necessary constitutional means and personal motives to resist encroachments of the others."

What's happening here is the collapse of that separation.

The Department of Energy is the regulator, the promoter, and the expediter. It writes the rules, approves the reactors, and provides concierge service to applicants. The reviewers report to the Secretary. The Secretary reports to the President. The President set a July 4 deadline for criticality. And the entire process happened without the public knowing the standards being applied.

There's no external check. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which normally regulates commercial reactors through a rigorous public process, has been bypassed. Some NRC staff have been loaned to DOE, but they're now working under DOE's loosened standards, reporting through DOE's chain of command.

When the regulator, the promoter, and the industry being regulated are all aligned toward the same goal, with the same deadline, under rules the public cannot see, you no longer have regulation. You have a partnership pursuing velocity.

Madison would recognize this. It's the problem of faction he warned about in Federalist 10: when a group with a shared interest gains control of the machinery of government, they will use it to advance that interest. The cure is transparency, competing powers, public accountability.

All of which have been suspended here.

## The Normalization

This is not about whether Small Modular Reactors are a good idea. Nuclear power may well be essential to meeting energy demands while reducing carbon emissions. There are legitimate debates about whether existing safety standards are too stringent, whether ALARA has been applied beyond what's reasonable, whether innovation is being unnecessarily delayed.

But those are debates that should happen in public, with expert testimony, public comment, environmental review, and congressional oversight. What's happening instead is the quiet rewriting of foundational safety principles to meet a symbolic deadline.

And once these reactors are operational, the new standards become the baseline. Future reactors will be built under these looser rules. The cuts to security requirements, environmental protections, worker safety standards, all of it becomes precedent. Temporary measures to meet an urgent deadline become permanent features of the regulatory landscape.

That's how extraordinary measures become normalized. Not through dramatic announcements, but through quiet internal revisions that no one sees until they're already in effect.

## What Citizens Should Be Asking

The question isn't whether the Department of Energy is technically permitted to revise its internal orders without public comment. It is.

The question isn't whether some existing nuclear safety standards might be overly burdensome. Some might be.

The question is this: In a constitutional republic, is it acceptable for an agency to rewrite safety standards governing experimental nuclear reactors, share those standards with the companies it regulates, and withhold them from the public?

If the answer is yes, on what principle? What limiting standard prevents this from becoming routine? What prevents other agencies from adopting the same approach, sharing new rules with regulated industries while keeping the public in the dark?

If the answer is no, what recourse exists? The orders were legally revised. The executive order creating the program came from the President. The oversight agency has been bypassed. The traditional regulatory process doesn't apply. The rules won't appear in the Federal Register. Congress hasn't intervened.

So who, exactly, is accountable?

That's the question citizens should be asking. Not whether nuclear power is good or bad. Not whether these particular reactors will be safe. But whether a government that rewrites safety standards in secret, shares them with industry before the public, and creates concierge teams to expedite approvals is still a government of, by, and for the people.

## The Test

When the first of these reactors achieves criticality, possibly on July 4, 2026, there will be a ceremony. Officials will speak about American innovation, energy independence, technological leadership. The President may attend. It will be presented as success.

But success measured how? By meeting a deadline? By achieving criticality? By satisfying industry partners?

Or by protecting public safety, maintaining transparency, preserving the accountability that makes self-government possible?

The reactors may operate without incident. The loosened security standards may prove adequate. The reduced environmental protections may cause no harm. The elimination of mandatory radiation minimization may not endanger workers. All of that is possible.

But even if every reactor operates safely, something will have been lost. The principle that safety standards governing activities that could harm the public should be developed in public. The norm that regulated industries should not see new rules before citizens do. The expectation that government agencies work for the people, not the sectors they regulate.

Those things, once lost, are hard to recover.

This isn't about nuclear power. It's about the quiet transfer of sovereignty from citizens to interests, from public accountability to private benefit, from transparent governance to expedited process.

In Union there is Strength. But union requires trust. And trust requires knowing what your government is doing, and why, and for whom.

The reactors are being built. The question is what else is being constructed alongside them.

pending.headline: When Elections Are Reopened
pending.content:
I spent years in uniform, and later in government service, understanding one principle above all others: legitimacy flows from process, and once process concludes, we accept the result.

That's what constitutional order requires.

On Wednesday, FBI agents in ballistic vests entered the Fulton County Election Hub in Georgia with a federal warrant. They loaded materials into trucks. They seized records from an election held more than four years ago. An election that was certified by Republican election officials. An election that survived hand recounts. An election whose results were upheld by dozens of courts, including judges appointed by the candidate who lost.

The Department of Justice sued Fulton County in December seeking "all used and void ballots, stubs of all ballots, signature envelopes, and corresponding envelope digital files from the 2020 General Election."

This isn't a criminal investigation into recent misconduct. This is the executive branch, now led by the candidate who disputed that election's results, deploying federal law enforcement to re-examine ballots from an election he lost.

The question isn't whether investigations can be legitimate. The question is what it means when a president uses the apparatus of federal law enforcement to revisit the election that made him a private citizen.

## The Record Speaks

The facts are not in dispute. Georgia's 2020 election was among the most scrutinized in American history. Biden won by 12,670 votes. The state conducted a hand recount of nearly five million ballots. The result held. Secretary of State Brad Raffensperger, a Republican who supported Trump, certified the outcome. Multiple audits followed. No widespread fraud was found.

Numerous courts rejected the legal challenges. Not on procedural grounds. On the merits.

In a recorded phone call, the losing candidate told Raffensperger: "I just want to find 11,780 votes, which is one more than we have. Because we won the state." Raffensperger refused. He followed the law instead of the president's instruction.

That was January 2, 2021. Two criminal indictments followed years later, one federal, one state, both charging election interference. The federal case ended when Trump returned to office. The state case collapsed amid prosecutorial error and was dismissed.

Now the federal government he leads has obtained a warrant to seize the materials from that election.

This is not investigation. This is revisitation.

## What Precedent Permits

The law allows investigations. Federal authority extends to election fraud when it occurs. No one disputes this.

But consider what is being normalized.

A candidate loses an election. He disputes the result publicly and through litigation. Courts reject his claims. State officials certify the outcome. He faces criminal charges for his efforts to overturn it. Those charges end when he regains power. Then his Department of Justice obtains warrants to seize the records of that same election, citing the same fraud claims that courts previously rejected.

This is not partisan. It is procedural.

What prevents the next administration from doing the same? What prevents any losing candidate, once returned to power, from deploying federal law enforcement to investigate the election they lost? If a warrant can be issued years later, on claims already adjudicated, when does an election truly end?

Finality is not a courtesy. It is a constitutional requirement. Without it, no transition of power is legitimate. Without it, every election remains provisional, subject to reopening when power shifts.

In Federalist No. 68, Hamilton wrote that the election process must be designed so "the office of President will never fall to the lot of any man who is not in an eminent degree endowed with the requisite qualifications." But he also understood that process must conclude. Elections are not永久 pendente lite.

## What Citizens Should Ask

Fulton County Commissioner Mo Ivory stood outside the election facility and said, "This is an assault on your vote."

That framing is incomplete. The question is not whether this targets one party's voters. The question is whether it targets the finality of elections themselves.

Ask this: If a future president who lost Georgia in 2024 returns to office in 2032, may that president's Justice Department obtain warrants to seize 2024 ballots, citing fraud claims rejected by courts in 2025? If the answer is yes, elections are never final. If the answer is no, explain the principle that distinguishes this case.

Ask this: Does a warrant's existence prove an investigation's legitimacy, or does legitimacy depend on what the investigation seeks to prove and why it is being conducted years after courts resolved the underlying claims?

Ask this: When federal agents in tactical gear enter local election offices to seize years-old materials, who is being investigated? The ballots, or the outcome?

The legal authority to investigate does not answer whether the investigation serves law or power. Courts authorize warrants based on probable cause. They do not assess whether reopening settled questions undermines constitutional order.

## The Framers' Warning

The Founders knew that power, once exercised, becomes precedent. They built the Constitution to constrain not just what government does, but what it can justify doing later.

Madison warned in Federalist No. 51: "If men were angels, no government would be necessary. If angels were to govern men, neither external nor internal controls on government would be necessary." We rely on institutional restraint because we cannot rely on leaders to restrain themselves.

When institutional norms erode, they do not collapse suddenly. They erode through individual acts that seem defensible in isolation but accumulate into precedent. A warrant is issued. Materials are seized. The process is legal. But the pattern is dangerous.

This is not about 2020. It is about what becomes permissible in 2032, 2040, 2048. It is about whether elections, once certified and litigated and recounted, remain closed, or whether they remain subject to federal investigation whenever the losing candidate later gains federal power.

## What We Are Witnessing

An election was held. It was certified. It was audited. It was litigated. It was recounted. Courts ruled. The outcome stood. The losing candidate faced charges for attempting to overturn it. He regained office. His Justice Department now deploys federal law enforcement to seize the materials from that election.

This is not a neutral act. It is a statement about what elections mean. If they can be reopened when power shifts, they are not democratic contests. They are provisional arrangements, subject to ratification by the next administration's investigators.

That is not the republic the Founders designed. That is not the system their Constitution protects. That is not compatible with the peaceful transfer of power.

The test is not whether today's warrant is legally defensible. The test is whether we accept that elections, once concluded, remain open to federal investigation by the candidates who lost them, once those candidates return to power.

If we accept that, we have accepted that elections never truly end. We have accepted that legitimacy flows not from voters and courts, but from whoever controls the FBI.

That question, unanswered, is why this still matters.

pending.headline: When Foreign Powers Encourage Dissolution
pending.content:
I spent years working in roles where respecting sovereignty wasn't an abstract principle. It was operational discipline. When you work across borders, in uniform or in civilian capacity, you learn that nations hold together through shared commitment, not just geography. And you learn that outside powers who encourage internal fracture are not acting as friends.

That's why the meetings between Alberta separatists and U.S. officials deserve attention beyond the partisan noise.

This isn't about whether Alberta has legitimate grievances with Ottawa. Regional tensions exist in every federal system. That's not unusual.

What's unusual is a Treasury Secretary publicly calling a Canadian province "a natural partner" while separatists conduct what they call "feasibility studies" on half-trillion-dollar credit lines with officials in Washington.

The White House says no commitments were made. Perhaps. But the meetings themselves are the message. They signal that dissolution is being treated as a respectable option, not a constitutional crisis. They suggest that one nation's internal democratic processes are proper subjects for another nation's strategic planning.

That crosses a line that used to be bright.

**The Pattern of Encouraged Fragmentation**

History offers clear lessons here. Outside powers rarely encourage separatist movements from altruistic motives. They do so when they perceive advantage in weakening a neighbor or rival.

Russia funded separatists in Ukraine. It supported movements in Georgia, Moldova, the Balkans. China courts Pacific island nations while their larger neighbors watch. The playbook is consistent: identify internal divisions, offer external support, present dissolution as empowerment.

The United States has historically opposed such tactics when aimed at allies. We supported Canadian unity during Quebec's referendums. We backed territorial integrity in Europe after the Cold War. The principle was clear: nations decide their own composition through their own democratic processes, without foreign interference.

What changed?

The answer appears to be that strategic interest now outweighs principle. Alberta has resources. An independent Alberta might be more compliant on pipelines, energy exports, continental security. The calculation is transparent.

But the calculation ignores what happens when major powers treat allied nations' unity as negotiable based on resource access.

**Sovereignty and Democratic Process**

Prime Minister Carney's response, telling U.S. officials to "respect Canadian sovereignty," states the principle plainly. So does Alberta Premier Smith's expectation that the U.S. leave discussions of provincial status to Canadians.

Both statements recognize something fundamental: the legitimacy of democratic choice depends on it being made freely, by the people it affects, without outside interference.

If Albertans genuinely wish to explore independence, that's their right through Canadian constitutional processes. But when a neighboring power offers financial backing and political encouragement, the decision is no longer wholly theirs. The thumb is on the scale.

This matters beyond Canada. If the United States can support separatism in a close ally based on resource interests, what prevents other powers from doing the same elsewhere? What prevents them from doing it here?

Consider: if China offered financial backing to a Hawaiian independence movement, or Russia supported Texas separatists, would we call that respecting democratic choice? Or would we call it what it is—strategic interference in another nation's integrity?

The principle doesn't change based on whose sovereignty is being undermined.

**What Citizens Should Ask**

The question isn't whether Alberta separatism is justified or likely. Polling suggests most Albertans oppose it. The counter-petition gathered hundreds of thousands of signatures.

The question is whether the United States government should be meeting with and encouraging separatist movements in allied democracies at all.

Because if the answer is yes—if strategic advantage justifies undermining allied unity—then we've abandoned a principle that has served both democracy and stability since 1945.

We've accepted that sovereignty is conditional, that territorial integrity is negotiable, that outside powers may properly interfere in other nations' internal democratic processes when it serves their interests.

That's not the position of a nation that respects the rule of law. That's the position of an empire managing provinces.

**The Test of Principle**

There's a reason the Founders worried about foreign influence. They understood that outside powers offering support rarely do so to strengthen self-governance. They do so to create dependencies, to gain leverage, to turn internal divisions into external opportunities.

Madison wrote in Federalist 43 about the necessity of preventing foreign interference in domestic affairs. Hamilton warned repeatedly about entangling alliances that compromised sovereignty. Both understood that free government requires insulation from external pressure.

The principle applies universally. When we encourage separatism in allied nations for strategic gain, we weaken not just their sovereignty but the entire framework that makes sovereignty meaningful.

And we invite others to do the same to us.

British Columbia's Premier Eby used strong language, calling such meetings "treason." That may overstate the legal case. But it captures the moral one.

Citizens who seek outside support for dissolving their nation aren't acting in pure democratic spirit. They're inviting foreign influence into a fundamentally internal question.

And officials who provide that support aren't respecting democracy. They're exploiting it.

**What Remains**

The meetings happened. The Treasury Secretary spoke. The signals were sent.

What matters now is whether this becomes accepted practice or recognized as a boundary crossed.

If democratic allies cannot rely on each other to respect their territorial integrity, then alliances mean nothing. If outside powers may properly encourage internal dissolution based on resource interests, then sovereignty becomes mere theater.

The question for American citizens is whether we want our government conducting itself this way. Whether we believe our strategic interests justify undermining allied unity. Whether we think other nations won't reciprocate.

Because they will.

This isn't about Alberta or Canada specifically. It's about whether there are still limits to what powerful nations do to weaker neighbors, even friendly ones.

If there aren't, say so clearly.

If there are, then these meetings should not have occurred, and the officials who held them should hear from citizens that encouraging allied dissolution crosses a line.

That's not politics. That's principle.

In Union there is Strength.
